comment_text: Your podcass are fantastic but I think the time is limiting your audience. Please, have shorts of your podcasts with the important information. One to two hour podcasts are too time consuming. Great information and I love hearing the conversation but I rarely watch the complete video because it just takes too much time. The few times I've watched them completely through it's been more background noise and I tune in and out. I've shared your videos with family and friends since I think the topics are very interesting but they don't watch it, it's too long. I've watched channels grow that actually have had this approach of having smaller clips, possibly four or five shorter videos of a 1 to 3 hour podcasts. The clips should be from 5 to 10 minutes and maybe one up to 15. I think you would find a bigger audience I know I would be a total fan of watching those. I think they can also inspire people to actually watch the complete video.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Bollocks! It's 2 hours, and 17 minutes long, you teased all the tips in the beginning, and I thought, this looks really interesting, and it surely is, but it's not "entertainmenment", it requires depth of thought and self reflection/pondering. I don't think most movies are that long, (movies being engineered to suck you in attention-wise, hence why we can sit through a harry potter marathon all day). I figured out from learning stuff on YouTube tutorials, (like, say, photography, what certain features reference and how to use them) and come to the conclusion that the brain can (generally speaking) retain up to about 7 to 9 minutes per session of simple, direct, bullshit-free/waffle-free learning before the brain starts to resist and buffer, goes to commercials, comes back disgruntled, thinking, "what the fuck have you been waffling on about for the last 45 minutes?! I clicked your vid to learn about "why you should use 'back-button focus' and you've told me fuck-all of any use other than bragging about yourself, and just straight fucking waffling, and showing off your shitty editing. Twat!" 52 minutes to NOT say what "photo genius" DOES in 7 minutes!

Don't get me wrong, I'm not knocking your videos, there's philosophy, psychology, and life-changing practical applications to be gleaned from it. I see you have different tips sections, "how to say no" how to spot a liar" "how to reply to snarkiness" or whatever, great, but if you broke them down into more digestible portions it would be easier to extract and absorb the relevant content, and other sections would be easier to watch as casual viewing. Plus, not only is there too much to tackle in one session, if you did break it down, not only would it be more accessible and easier to absorb and digest, you would also make more money. Win-win for everybody! 🎉
author: @mickb69

comment_text: This is a rich conversation between Steven and Jefferson. My advice, if you want to transform a negative relationship, treat the person like they’re already a friend. It won’t be easy and you won’t feel authentic, though I guarantee after 5-6 exchanges, the other person will start to shift their behavior. For example, sit next to them in the meeting, give them friendly eye contact, laugh at their joke, even if it’s not funny (cause you know you do that with your friends), offer to grab them a coffee and watch the transformation!

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
If Mr Jefferson Fisher is ashamed of Jesus then Jesus will be ashamed of him and my reason for saying this is because when I listen to his podcast videos, I'm not seeing where he gives the glory an honor to Jesus, for giving him the wisdom and understanding on how to respond to people in conversation and this is according to the Holy Spirit who I asked for him to let me know am I wrong in saying anything to him about this, and I heard the word LUKEWARM, and Jesus says in Revelation that anyone who is lukewarm towards him, that he will vomit him out of his mouth. And I don't honestly believe that he wants to be viewed that way by Jesus, but; The word of God also preaches against us Christians getting caught up in the cares and riches of this world and forgetting about Jesus our Lord and Savior, which I believe this Man who believes he is the master of communication, but he's definitely not giving God the full honor and glory for what he's been given by God and that's the wisdom and understanding that he's using but he's claiming the glory for himself. Oh yeah sometimes we mention God's name, but I'm referring to is the faithfulness of giving God 100% on her and glory and not retaining any of that glory for ourselves and that's what I'm concerned about and this man should be concerned about also according to the word of God! 

ANY person who preaches the Word of God but fails to give God full honor and glory is not considered a faithful Christian because the ultimate goal of preaching is to bring glory to God, and their actions or motives would likely contradict this core principle. While not definitive, a lack of devotion to God's glory in one's actions, including preaching, can be an indicator of a more serious issue, such as focusing on self-glory, fame, or reward rather than God's supremacy and sovereignty.
 
Why Giving God Glory is Essential
Core Purpose of Preaching
: The primary goal of Christian preaching is to exalt God and restore His dominion in people's hearts, according to Desiring God. 

Biblical Mandate
: Scripture, such as 1 Corinthians 10:31 and Colossians 3:23, instructs believers to do everything for God's glory, whether it's preaching or personal life. 

Indicator of True Faith
: A lack of focus on God's glory can reveal underlying issues, such as a desire for personal power, fame, or earthly rewards instead of God's honor. 

What It Means to Give God Full Honor and Glory
Focus on God's Supremacy
: It means recognizing and promoting God's absolute sovereignty, power, and infinite being in one's preaching. 
Preaching for God's Sake, Not Self
: The true preacher is a vessel for God's message, not the source of it, ensuring that the focus remains on God, not personal achievement❗

Integrity in Motive
: Actions and words should be shaped by the desire to honor God rather than to achieve personal gain or gain followers.

Why Lack of Glory is a Sign of Unfaithfulness

Divergence from God's Will
: Any action that does not glorify God is seen as a sin, obstructing God's will and commands according to the word of God!  

Self-Exaltation
: By not giving God the full credit, a person is essentially trying to take the place that God deserves, mirroring the downfall of Satan who sought glory for himself.

Like Jensen Franklin says words have power and if that power isn't used to openly give God the glory and honor for the wisdom and understanding that we know he gave us, then it's a sin not to publicly give him the honor for it instead of quietly leaving him out of the conversation most of the time not giving him that glory and honor that is truly do him. 

Regarding the righteous who may sin: "Again, when a righteous person turns from their righteousness and does evil... But if you do warn the righteous person not to sin and they do not sin, they will surely live because they took warning, and you will have saved yourself".
Consequences of silence: If the watchman fails to warn the righteous person, and that person falls into sin and dies, God will hold the watchman accountable. However, if the warning is given and the righteous person heeds it, they will live, and the watchman will have fulfilled their duty.

comment_text: The word is converse, not conversate.   Conversate it is a non-standard back-formation of "conversation," with the correct standard verb being "converse". While it is a real word that has been in use for  years and is understood, it is often viewed as informal, dialectal, or even incorrect, and should be avoided in formal writing and speech.

comment_text:
To every soul reading this — we may be strangers, but from my heart, I’m sending you wishes of strength, peace, radiant health, and a life filled with love and joy. You matter. 🙏🏻🍀❤

Words carry power, and the way we speak can shape how others see us. Using certain filler words can unintentionally make you seem less confident, even if you’re telling the truth. By becoming aware and practicing mindful speech, anyone can communicate with authority and authenticity.

James, a marketing manager, realized he was saying “like” and “just” constantly during presentations. After consciously removing these words, his team noticed his confidence soared, and his ideas were taken more seriously. He now speaks with clarity and impact in every meeting.

Thank you, The Speaking Coach, for revealing this simple but powerful insight! 🗣💡

Have you ever noticed yourself using filler words that weaken your message? Which word do you think you

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
In this video, Jefferson Fisher, a board-certified trial attorney, shares his expertise on effective communication and conflict resolution. He emphasizes the profound impact of our words and offers practical strategies to enhance conversational skills.
Here are some of the key learnings:
 * Responding to Disrespect: When faced with belittling or disrespectful behavior, instead of retaliating, Fisher suggests a three-step approach:
   * Maintain 5 to 7 seconds of silence [00:10].
   * Ask the person to repeat what they said [00:15].
   * Simply say "Thank you" [01:02:54], which signifies that you acknowledge their true character.
 * The Power of Not "Winning" Arguments: Fisher argues against the common desire to "win" an argument, stating that it often leads to losing the relationship [40:56]. He encourages viewing arguments as something to "unravel" [01:01], suggesting the question "What am I missing?" as a powerful tool for difficult conversations [01:03].
 * Three Pillars of Effective Communication: Fisher outlines three crucial aspects of impactful communication:
   * Say it with Control: This involves managing your fight or flight response by focusing on your breath [01:27:14]. He introduces the "conversational breath" technique, which involves two quick inhales through the nose followed by a slow exhale through the mouth or nose [01:31:22]. This helps maintain a calm and analytical mindset. Additionally, slowing down your speech conveys more control and confidence [02:03:42].
   * Say it with Confidence: Confidence is not something you possess beforehand but an outcome of assertive actions [02:44:00]. Using an "assertive voice" involves being direct yet kind, balancing passivity and aggression [02:50:58]. Fisher advises eliminating hesitant words like "just" to sound more assertive [02:56:55]. He also highlights that confident individuals tend to speak less, as they have nothing to prove, while insecure individuals often over-explain [03:07:07].
   * Say it to Connect: This involves getting curious about the other person and understanding their underlying beliefs and struggles [04:47:08]. Fisher proposes a conversational framework: state what you want to discuss, explain how you want the conversation to end, and seek their buy-in [03:51:00]. This creates an "invisible contract" that encourages a more productive dialogue.
 * Dealing with Difficult People: When encountering someone who is easily triggered or disrespectful, Fisher advises creating distance and delaying the conversation [05:59:00]. Instead of engaging in the moment, suggest discussing it later when both parties are calmer [05:59:00]. When responding to insults, repeating the insult back to the person or asking "Did you mean for that to sound rude?" can shift the focus back to them and their intent [01:04:46].
 * The Art of Saying "No": Fisher provides a framework for setting boundaries and saying "no" effectively, especially for people-pleasers [01:20:10]. He suggests starting with a clear "no" and then adding gratitude, rather than leading with apologies or excuses [01:21:49]. For example, instead of "I'm terribly sorry, but I can't make it," say "I can't make it this time, but thank you so much for inviting me" [01:23:40].
 * Impact of Words on Life: Fisher emphasizes that words have a ripple effect, influencing not only immediate interactions but also long-term relationships, careers, and even future generations [02:05:01]. He uses the analogy of glasses of water to illustrate that you cannot fill a full glass; people must first empty their own thoughts and beliefs through questioning before they can be receptive to new ideas [04:51:00].
author: @tspirate

comment_text:
🤨 How to handle disrespectful:

- "Be like water": giống như mình né nước, uyển chuyển gạt qua hoặc né qua. Cụ thể:
 + Im lặng trong khoảng 5s đến 7s. 
 + Hỏi lại: did u say that to hurt/upset me? Did u mean for that to be rude?How does it make u feel when u said that to me? (Hỏi lại 1 cách thật lòng nha chứ ko phải kiểu hỏi khích, vì đôi khi người ta ko cố ý thật).
 + Và rồi người đó sẽ phải thừa nhận chủ ý của câu insult đó, thường là họ sẽ bắt đầu giải thích cho bản thân 🤣

🫣 Nếu mình trả lời lại insult với sự tức giận, buồn bã thì mình đã gave them the dopamine hit, and that's exactly what they want! Nhưng nếu mình hỏi lại, hoặc bắt người đó nhắc lại, họ đột nhiên phải tự thừa nhận lời nói đó là khá bất lịch sự.
author: @thamphan5884

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!

author: @celestehogan5907

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
3. Say to connect:
- Nghĩa là mình nói chuyện để hiểu mình hiểu người kia hơn; và để người kia hiểu mình muốn nói gì. Người ta hoặc mình sẽ ko cần phải happy hay đồng ý 100%, chỉ là để đối phương hiểu mình muốn giải thích điều gì. 

- Công thức "What + How it ends":
 + What: mình sẽ nói về vấn đề gì.
 + How it ends: sau cuộc nói chuyện này, chúng ta sẽ giải quyết được vấn đề gì. 

- When you talk only to win an argument, you will lose the relationship  Mình sẽ thắng được gì, sự im lặng của người kia, sự lúng túng mỗi khi chạm mặt người đó... Hãy xem mỗi argument là cơ hội để tìm được "nút thắt bị rối" của cọng dây mà 2 người đang nắm ở 2 bên. Và thể hiện cho người đó thấy là mình muốn gỡ rối cùng người đó, chứ ko phải muốn thăng họ.
author: @thamphan5884

1. Say with control - để tránh mình rớt vô trạng thái fight or flight:

- 13:07 "Let your breath be your first voice": hít sâu => giữ hơi rồi hít sâu thêm hơi nữa => thở ra bằng mũi (ko phát ra tiếng càng tốt).

- Pause: dừng lại vài giây, xong rồi mới trả lời => Người nghe sẽ cảm giác mình là người đáng tin, vì mình thật sự dành time để suy nghĩ về câu hỏi đc nhận, và cẩn thận trả lời.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
It's not always about "choosing". 

First, it's part of their training to argue for either side. 

Second, "everyone is entitled to legal counsel" and a "FAIR trial".  Choosing to not represent someone sends a bad message.  The message might be "I am not a criminal  attorney" or something else related to expertise.

The lawyer's job might be "public defender".  We often hear of politicians who were trained as lawyers spending their early career in this position.  Hillary Clinton, for example, was recorded in a private conversation many years later discussing a trial of someone she didn't want to defend but she had to.

Imagine a company or an individual who has legal counsel on call.  How does it look if that person has to change lawyers for the particular situation.  Especially if someone a great wealth is using a public defender.  Anyone who knows the business relationship will see it as suspicious (and lawyers, judges, reporters or investigators can find out).  If there's an ethical reason that the lawyer is backing out, it's like letting everyone make  their own worst assumptions.  

Most of the reasoning is really about doing their job well an being fair to their client.

Another issue is that a lawyer could drop somebody simply because they think they can't when that case.  That would simply be about the ego of the attorneys.  But you can see how that would also poison the pool. 

Oddly, your question assumes ethical superiority, but in the judicial world, giving a fair chance is the flip side of the ethical situation.

The last thing you would want to happen is for the case to be thrown out because the trial was unfair and the attorney's did not do a good job!
author: @KweenOtW

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
A movie is approximately 2 hours. A school lesson is 40 minutes. A You Tube video is 25 to 30 minutes. Don't make 2 hour 17 minute videos because few people are going to watch two people talk for two hours, let alone remember more than about 5 to 10 minutes of what was actually said. The longer the video, the less people are going to remember. 

Common sense... 25 to 30 minutes... 4 or 5 key points....quick summary at the end.  The listener is going to pay more attention and likely to remember what is said. Two hours is too much to keep a track of and remember. That is why they don't have two hour lectures in schools.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I eventually started to realize that the thing I wanted for myself was for others to not have ammo to use against me. So I live my life trying my best to make sure I don't give people anything to hold against me. It basically boils down to treating others how I want to be treated. If someone is snappy and rude, I definitely get heated inside, but I know that there's probably something in them that has little or nothing to do with me and not to take it personally. When you respond with calmness to others who are not calm, it may not fix things, but it definitely doesn't escalate things like being hostile back would. It's hard to walk that line though of not being a door mat either

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
TL;DR: Anyone with ADHD have problems interrupting people?

What an exceptional interview and insightful discussion!  So much to learn here and apply to our own professional lives.

I work in a senior leadership role at a large corporation.  Much of the usual corporate scenarios: fast-paced environment, constant back-to-back meetings, etc.  I was diagnosed with ADHD more recently in my late 40s.  I know I often jump in too early, at times cutting people off, and have been trying to force myself to try to break this habit this past year.  However, each time I do so, I then tend to forget what I was going to say, unless I literally scribble down a note to remind myself.  I love this idea of incorporating these 5-7 pauses, etc., but for those of you struggling with the same, how do you finally get there?  I know it takes practice, but starting to get a bit impatient here.  I know interrupting isn ‘t professional, but at times it’s like my thoughts just come out.  Who are these types of people that we could get some help from?  Are they coaches?

comment_text: I retired from a professional government job as a programmer, but I love programming and want to continue by transferring this skill to game programming. I'm also interested in being an instructor or working part-time as a web developer. These possibilities motivate me to study different areas related to these goals. When I've conversed with people about this, they still ask me, "Why are you doing that?". On one of these occasions, the conversation was interrupted, so I decided not to return to that topic. On another occasion, another person asked the same question, but followed that up with a statement that communicated that they thought that they and others would think it would be crazy or insane to be interested in such things when they're retired. I allowed both these conversations to end because I believed they really weren't asking a question, but communicating the fact that they thought my interests were bizarre, weird, or crazy. Would there be a better response?

comment_text:
Loved this, and just subscribed. Also just bought Mr. Fisher's book on Audible. 

Regarding verbal fillers: I recall reading some time ago that people who use sounds like um, uh, er, etc. frequently do so to pause to think of the best way to say what they want to communicate or find the right word. Used occasionally they can be useful, but excessive can be annoying and stop the flow of conversation. Actual words like "Like", "okay" and "right" are different, and I find they almost always distract from the message. The latter two I find especially annoying when they end every other sentence and are inflected as a question - I just nod politely but inside I am hollerring "No, not okay!".  LOL

comment_text:
Just as a point of interest: in addition to “trial lawyers” there are others specializing in estates, wills, and trusts. These may go to trial once in awhile, but so rarely that they wouldn’t describe themselves as *trial lawyers*.

Also there are patent attorneys, and again, they may go to trial, but rarely.  They typically wouldn’t describe themselves as trial lawyers.

Then there are corporate lawyers and they, too, may go to trial, but some may be assigned by their corporate legal dept. to do mostly legal research, to oversee record keeping, to submit or to sign off on agreements and court documents.

Trial lawyers, on the other hand, are often prosecutors, defense attorneys, family law attorneys (who handle many divorce and custody cases), or others who expect many of their cases to require them to go to court and argue their case before a judge or arbitrator. Other trial lawyers may specialize in immigration, personal injury, dui/dwi, etc. Quite a few court appearances will often go with these  specialties.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
1. 5-7 second SILENCE - - Breathe - 
“Capture the Calm”
2. ASK them to REPEAT 
3. Engage with (3)positive ideas (not argument) - controlled speech - SLOW down 
4. Be CONFIDENT - Use assertive voice w/ NECESSARY words. Speak truth. Avoid certain words (just, like…)
4. Look at the intent of why he is saying this.
Talk to connect - understand. Win the relationship, not the argument.

Frame the conversation 
1)Set goal
2)Say outcome
3)See Agreement … “help me find the knot”
Be curious about person’s belief - to empty/ unravel the knot / meet him where he is (be aware of triggers - add distance)/ 


Well worth the listening - thank you.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: My mom wasn’t good at communicating. She was critical and judgmental. Her whole life was lived in a state of disappointment. You couldn’t help her. It seemed more like a personality flaw to me. She enjoyed arguing, she would pick a fight even before you had your coffee. I refused to argue with her. She liked to ask me every morning if today was going to be a good day. The implication was that it was your fault if the day was going to be good or not. I always said very calmly that I didn’t know mom, we will have to wait and see.  I would take my coffee and go back to my room. It was very hard since I was the caregiver for both parents until they passed away. All I can say was that I did my best even though she was constantly disappointed in everything that I did. I refuse to let it ruin the life I have left even though she tried to do that to me too. She was on her deathbed and I told her that I loved her. She glared at me with the meanest look in her eyes. I told myself that was her way and I didn’t let it ruin my life. The problem was hers, not mine and that is the way I live my life.

comment_text: I'm I wrong that I don't think she deserved you?  Why was it your burden to deal with such a cruel and unpleasant person?  Our parents give us life but they don't own us.  It's not our job or obligation to keep ourselves available to be abused by them.  The parent/child relationship is meant to be loving and she failed you every day.  She was a failure as a parent.  So for me, I my power is maintaining a respectful distance from my weird mother.  I don't go NC but I did move across the country so that she could not infiltrate my daily life and trigger me.  I guess I could see your willingness to subject and expose yourself to her negativity as some sort of grand Buddhist meditation on nonattachment to suffering.  But for me, my impulse is always to protect my inner child and to exercise my power.  To save my inner child from dysfunction and to be her hero.  No one intervened when i was an actual child but I sure as heck can save "her" now.  I don't think there is anything particularly noble about remaining loyal to a parent that chose to give me life and then deprived me of stability and love my entire life.  However, I do weirdly find your stoicism admirable.  I just feel, too, that I want more for you than to have remained exposed to that level of negativity throughout your whole entire life.  I guess each person's individual choices and path is neither right nor wrong, it's just our individual choices.  But I hope you didn't martyr yourself and give up a more love-filled life because of some misguided loyalty and obligation to your emotional abuser.  xo

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Wholly disagree about word fillers. They are massively annoying, and need to be avoided at all times, because what you casually do is the  pattern for what you will do under fire.

If you don’t have words to say, don’t say them. Word fillers make you sound unsure of yourself and lower your credibility. 

A simple pause is far better than word fillers. Don’t panic, keep your composure, and a pause will make you appear far more thoughtful than word fillers.

Even more important is to absolutely eliminate foul language from your speech, as that automatically, exponentially lowers your credibility and the value of any of your statements.

This is not because of morality, but because it is crude. Crudeness rarely enhances what you have to say.

However, if you speak to a wide range of people, you can lose those who don’t want to listen to unnecessary babble.
author: @PatShepherd-lf2vj

comment_text: 1:07:11 "Dopamine, the feel good hormone". Dopamine is not a feel good hormone. Ask any who knows neurobiology. Serotonine is, not dopamine. Dopamine is the hormon that makes you do things that gives you seretonine. When you buy a ticket in a lottery, that gives you dopamine, when you win you get serotonin, the feel good hormone. Dopamine makes you climb a tree for taking down a fruit. Eating the fruit gives you serotonin. When making rats have no dopamine, they eat food if you feed them directly in their mouth, but if the food is a feet away from them, they don´t go to the food and starve to death.

comment_text: I enjoyed this so much I watched the whole video. However, I think a lot of this doesn't help me deal with narcissistic people who genuinely don't care about people but themselves and maybe their dog. It sucks because you can leave someone with silence and they will match your energy without apologizing and I may never see a change. I know I shouldn't seek an apology and I'm glad that these skills I can  apply to my own life and own my inner child/shadow self. My main focus is on the consistency of thinking before I speak, if at all. I was taught this as a child, but I think years of abuse made me overlook it, and in hindsight, I resented most of the messages I was taught growing up despite the discipline. Thank you guys for sitting here and having this talk.

comment_text: A Lawyer and an Attorney are not the same thing.  Words matter.  This fellow should have known better.  A Trial Attorney is not the same thing as an Attorney.  This is basic set logic.  Within the domain of Lawyers is a set called Attorneys.  Within the set of Attorneys is the subset of Trial Attorneys.  The best synonym for Trial Attorney is probably Litigator.  Trial Attorneys are a rare breed.  There are well over a million lawyers in the Untied States ( just over 1.3 million ) but there are only about 7000 Trial Attorneys.  In other words a teeny tiny fraction of lawyers become Trial Attorneys.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I have a terrible habit of repeating myself over and over as though the person or group I'm talking to didn't hear me, and to the point that I set myself up to be ignored.  Having said that, I have severe hearing loss (60% with hearing aids)  that has occurred over time.  I progressed in life retiring as a program manager.  When I look back at my conversational abilities I shudder at how absurd I must have sounded.  I feel the hearing loss, not being fully engaged in conversations that I initiated then being ignored has been a significant life stumbling block.  I feel as a result I have some really irritating ticks or bad habits that drive my spouse insane.  Incessant humming or nonsense little songs that make zero sense but I somehow find comfort in; it drive me crazy so you can imagine how it must make my wife feel.   I recently turned 78 (March), I'm 100% disable vet though mobile and cognitive and I have significant PTSD.  I have spent my entire adult life either as a combatant or in combat support efforts globally, spending 3+ years in Vietnam and 8+ years in Middle East (Afghanistan/Iraq).  Level of responsibility was as Program Manager for theater U.S. Army aviation assets (helicopter maintenance) and managing up to 4,000 combat support contractors.  In a nut shell, I could not extricate myself from war even to the point of seeing my wife for a two week period every year then back to the desert which was my own personal insanity.  Finally giving it up and retired!  But my communication skills have always haunted me.  I suppose the icing on the cake is I have zero friends, lack the desire to have outside friends.  Wish I had sorted what ails me a lot earlier in life.  Thanks for your great show.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
For starters, using persuasive to win = manipulation. It may work in some cases to run smoothly, but I would question, does one use this method controlling method may cut a person, especially if they are the victim in a partnership relationship. This is why people get physical because they can't express themselves any other way.
Not saying it's right either. This could put a person in danger if you don't really know how far a person will go if they feel trapped in conversation no matter how calm you say things. Flight by leaving is sometimes can be a survival tactic. Example, a woman's weapon is her control articulating her words while her partner doesn't have these skills. It's an observation I've watched in sensitive situations with couples going through separation when children are involved or heading for divorce dividing assets. The person showing anger with passion, doesn't necessarily mean their the perpetrator. Like getting lost in the sauce... 
It's an art to use words and how it comes across in the tone and facial expression used to calm a situation. 
This has been an interesting perspective and demonstration watching this show. Thank you

comment_text:
Noooo, insecure people are very loud, confidence on the other hand is very quiet. Nooooo refer back to charles bukowski where he wrote "the problem with the world is that the intelligent people are full of doubts while the stupid ones are full of confidence."

Not confident people, but SECURE people. You speak of insecurity so the opposite is being secure. Insecure individuals will always project confidence because its pride that helps compensate for what they believe they lack. This is why youll always hear absolutism in their statements. Never, always.. they are SURE of themselves as if they can predict the future with absolute certainty. 

The opposite is that the secure ones stay quiet because they know they can be wrong and theyre okay with it, they know that saying too much and becoming too confident is not condusive to their growth because they prefer to listen and learn, and learning means they have to first accept they dont know.

And so theyre comfortable with doubting themselves because its nothing personal, theyre not advocating for their ego, theyre advocating for the truth, and the truth is we know so little. 

So no, confidence isnt always observed from secure individuals, theyre almost always exercised by the insecure. And with their dedication to save face, their confidence aids to solidify their ignorance.

The saddest part is, because the stupid ones are unaware of how lacking they truly are, they are the most likely to get promoted. The more aware someone is, the more nervous they become because theyre now aware of their own ignorance. 

And so were left with the dilemma of how the world has long accepted that one needs to be loud when one is confident. Because how could you possibly speak at the highest volume if you dont have confidence? The shy ones on the other hand, the lacking of confidence, will always be hesitant, always careful and never rushing. They have nothing to prove so theyll appear quietly lacking of confidence and lose any chance of being promoted because they wont even bother to ask.
author: @w0wNow

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Have the patience to know the person behind the words- wow! So true! I learned this long ago, in a real world scenario very similar to the example given!  I'm a groomer and had an elderly client that had been coming to me with her little Maltese for 2 or 3 years and one time she called back after picking the dog up and complained very loudly, almost aggressively, about the groom. She said a lot of things that were simply not true, I knew how the dog looked when it left, but this was very out of character for this client, as she was always really sweet. So I told her I was sorry she was unhappy, and that I had given the dog the same haircut it had been getting but I'd be glad to do it over for her and then I asked if she was OK, saying she sounded stressed out beyond the dog grooming situation- she broke down crying, her husband of almost 50 years had passed away a couple weeks before and she was not doing well at all!😢 I stayed on the phone with her, talking to her, being empathetic, giving her a safe space to vent her hurt, fear, and sadness- I found out that he had always handled the bank account and the bills and other legal things and she was scared and confused about taking care of herself in that regard, as well as her sadness at his loss. After she worked through all those feelings, she ended up telling me that there was really nothing wrong with the dog, she was just lashing out from her pain and she apologized to me! I found out where she lived, it was only about half a mile from my shop, and offered to come and pick the dog up for her and drop off after when she needed grooming, to try and help her out, since she had very limited mobility. She ended up being one of the best clients I ever had, and she was so appreciative, it was reward enough for me just seeing the smile on her face when I would come to the house❤ I would always go in and visit when I dropped the dog off, I knew she was lonely and it really brightened her day❤ I also showed her how to write checks and balance her checkbook, and I would even make out the checks for her bills at first, and let her sign them❤ I cried like a little kid the day her son called me and told me she passed away- I've never forgotten her, all these years later- all from taking a moment to find the "person behind the words"❤❤❤
author: @richellmcknight446

comment_text:
One I tend to agree wth Fisher's premise, yet in an argument, in particular, the statements vocalized in reaction, rather than response to your conversational partner's delivery, is said with meaning, and it is meant. To say a person says something "they didn't mean" is inherently false. 

Everything is said with both purpose and meaning. We, as people, often inaccurately present our honest intentions and understandings and attempt to cover that failure with a statement like "I didn't mean that/mean to say that," and unfortunately that ends up being a falsehood; i.e., a lie and a point of dishonesty to both your conversational partner and to themselves.

The use of an active pause, in a conscious state as the method presented by Fischer, which lends to a purposive application of dark psychology and manipulation, which doesn't surprise me coming from a "trained attorney." Attorneys are linguistic manipulators, which given that psychological association and the demonstrated application, may lend an observant person to pick up on pathologies related to those that regularly apply a hyperconscious direction of course and results orientated "conversations".

This form of conversational construction, particularly as Fischer presents it, demonstrates the pathological characteristics of masking; a method of persona control utilized by sociopaths. 

This "conversation" sounds like ones conducted and utilized by pathological narcissists with high-level associative sociopathy.

This is just a "much more articulate" version of politiciansb in my opinion and observation.

comment_text:
Voir Dire~to speak the truth!
About that "sweaty" attorney--I have an actual uncontrollable condition known as generalized hyperhidrosis. When I was younger, it mainly presented in my hands and feet, which believe it or not, are two similar but sort of unrelated conditions (i.e., they cannot both be resolved utilizing one mode of treatment, and the surgery to correct each one is apparently different). Nobody including me really noticed the significance that, when overheated, I literally sweat out of every pore of my body. Fortunately for myself and others, lol, I am not odiferously offensive; it can, however, be extremely awkward in work and social settings and worse with additional heat factors plus menopause (tmi, lol). My solution? While I don't necessarily announce it right off the bat, if I begin having an issue and sense discomfort (and as mentioned, often and almost immediate sensing of distrust) from others, I explain that I have a diagnosed health condition wherein my pores do not necessarily cooperate with my inner thermostat. Having a sense of humor and approaching that with honesty and authenticity is key. 😊

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Such a fantastic point about not looking to win an argument or win the conversation! I watch so many people who don't remember what active listening feels like because they are up in their heads gaming the entire conversation. I recently began to wonder something about this, low-key: are only children less likely to do that (listening to talk or "win" instead of actively listening and responding in kind) than kids with siblings, or more than a certain number of siblings? My unbiological sister/best friend and I are both singular children with smaller families even outside of our parents, and we are both extremely empathetic. We also grew up primarily talking and interacting with only adults. Conversely, my husband plus some of our courtesy cousins who hail from larger families (3 siblings or more), seem to have major territorial issues surrounding communication. And not meaning that at all as a dig to either, because both present unique challenges when trying to build better listening and communication skills. 🤙💚

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
I'm a public speaker. A few of my colleagues were telling me about another speaker who was struggling trying to connect with his audience. They said he had good content, but he seemed to be more focused on completing his "script", rather than slowing down to get the connection. He spoke way too fast. I told them something I heard once from Tony Robbins, and have never forgotten - 90% of communication is non-verbal.  People know how to build walls for the words you say. What they're not skilled in is building walls for things you never verbally said, but communicated just the same...

Don't discard the value of being purposely silent... of letting your audience hear you take a breath. Don't discard what the simple tone of your voice can say, moreso than your words. Hand gestures, and facial expressions have communicated far more than we give them credit for.  

#TheRobLettShow

Robert Houghwout Jackson (February 13, 1892 – October 9, 1954) was an American lawyer, jurist, and politician who served as an associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court from 1941 until his death in 1954. He had previously served as United States Solicitor General and United States Attorney General, and is the only person to have held all three of those offices. Jackson was also notable for his work at the Nuremberg trials prosecuting Nazi war criminals following World War II. Jackson developed a reputation as one of the best writers on the Supreme Court and one of the most committed to enforcing due process as protection from overreaching federal agencies.

comment_text: I say how I feel but i recognize it's ok to have an unexpressed thought. I generally don't get embarrassed and rarely lie or exaggerate. I've had an interesting life and have lots of good stories. I talk a lot but pause between thoughts to give others a chance. When someone else is talking I let go of what I was going to say and listen. I usually don't talk peopled into doing things and don't care if they believe me or not. I don't mind arguing or dropping it without resolving it. I don't take things personally. I don't put much effort into my relationship It's easy spend time with people I like spending time with.. I retired more than 20 years ago so I'm not forced to spend much time with people I don't care for. I can annoy some people and some annoy me and that's ok in small doses. My most common response to an insult to smile and say "So" Life is too short so you might as well enjoy it.

Wow! When Jefferson Fisher talked about what he would have told his younger self that really hit home. I was the oldest daughter of nine children and put in charge of so many things at a very young age. I felt like much of my childhood was helping my mother, whether it was babysitting, peeling 5 pounds of potatoes, cleaning, cooking, laundry.  Every day picking up 2 gallons of milk on the way home from school,  changing diapers.
So when I had kids, I NEVER asked them or my EX to do anything. And they never offered. Messed up. Only now, that my kids are grown (divorced when they were young) and I’m retired can I live in the present moment.

Jefferson, please look into the Dutch communication culture. The Dutch communication style is extremely honest, direct, concise, and effective, but still respectful and friendly. A lot of people have a problem with it. There's no small talk. Things are not sugar coated. In business meetings, you get straight to the point. You face your mistakes head on without hesitation or shame. Some people misinterpret the directness as rude but they need to understand there is zero malice in it. The Dutch are known for being very focused on problem solving and as long as it's honest, they don't really have much of a problem with criticism. They probably just don't realize in other cultures we're a little less comfortable with brutal honesty.

Anyway.... Do check it out! It's fascinating. Do a search for "Dutch Directness" and watch a couple videos if for no other reason than to get some really good laughs because seeing the reactions of Brits and Americans is priceless.
author: @drew-in-ca

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I have taught ESL/EFL and Academic presentations at Japanese universities for 30 years. That chart you show of the ums, ers, etc., shows fillers. They have three specific functions: 1. They make the conversation casual and informal and put the speaker and listener on the same level, meaning there is no hierarchy or authority. So, they can be used to effectively destroy unwanted authority in conversation. But, 2. They also can establish a mutual friendship. Without them, starting a new friendship within a group may prove difficult. One reason for this is 3. Fillers fill silent gaps in an unplanned conversation while we think of what to say. So, they keep the conversation flowing without unwanted gaps and pauses. Someone else will jump into any gap in a group conversation, resulting in the silent participant losing their position at least temporarily. So, fillers help a newbie, or anyone else stay in the conversation. Without fillers, what one says will likely sound too formal, out of place, and not friendly. So, use fillers if you're trying to make friends or establish a friendship. Presentations are entirely different, as you know from your podcasts. Now, you don't want fillers. As a presenter, one is, by default, the authority, teacher or informer. You have to hold that position. Furthermore, as your guest noted, pauses can be very useful in a presentation for the reasons he gave. Forgetfulness in a formal presentation is a pause and acceptable if you don't show the forgetfulness. A presenter needs to keep the audience's attention; a pause will get their attention and give people time to think about what was said and to catch up if their attention wanders. So, don't use fillers in a presentation, or you'll destroy your look of confidence and position as an authority or teacher. However, do use pauses to clarify and establish a connection. Gestures are another interesting and different matter.
author: @クリスロックCHRISLOCK

comment_text:
This is painful because it is so good and cuts to the middle of some of my absolute greatest shortcomings.  I want to say I needed this but that's only true if I am successful in embracing what I learned and applying it to the point where it helps me avoid falling into the traps I have automatically fallen into most of my life.  And that's why it's painful.

I don't want it to be a thing where I see someone, put that person on a pedestal, and fail to be changed.

comment_text: @@reppi8742 - Ironically, your perspective comes off as weakness to me.  A person can rightly be moved with great passion, justly irate over being victimized or disrespected, and use some choice swear words or not.  Seeing and hearing the person in the spirit of what they are conveying is a way of showing respect, love, compassion to them.  Also, are you so sure that you didn't truly hurt someone and are not taking responsibility for it, yet write off the person confronting you because they are swearing?  Why not be open to contexts where a person can use salty language ( due to pain, passion, or humor ) even if it is not your particular cup of tea.  Sometimes a swear word can be more than appropriate.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Video claims liars use "never" to overemphasize denial (e.g., "I would never do that").
Suggests honest people avoid absolutes, using simpler statements (e.g., "I didn’t do that").
Argues "never" signals overcompensation, tied to a psychological need to deflect doubt.
Encourages noticing word choice as a clue to dishonesty.
Concept is engaging and ties to behavioral analysis, where emphatic denials can raise suspicion.
Offers a simple, practical tip to think about language in daily life.
Oversimplifies lie detection—context, tone, and habits are equally important.
"Never" isn’t a foolproof sign of lying.
Lacks hard evidence, leaning more toward pop psychology than a serious tool.
Effective as a quick, thought-provoking idea but not a reliable rule.
author: @SLAYINGVR

comment_text:
Your work and perspective seems solid, but interestingly your work is actually that of a professionally trained mediator. Mediators are trained and educated conflict resolution specialists. Why not work as a mediator too? Or instead of? 

Lawyers, trial attorneys, are steeped and educated in the adversarial legal system by its very nature of course. (Though some law schools are starting to teach mediation) 

Between lawyers, the “bulldog” who fights better wins more. “Settling” out of court becomes the holy grail of lawyers and getting to settlement (often over years of emailing to and fro between lawyers) is a lucrative process for them. trial attorneys amass great wealth in the long process of preparing for court, waiting for court and proceeding through trial.

Why not get people out of court and into mediation given that you have these skills? Mediation will save them literally thousands upon thousands upon thousands of dollars and even better years of stress and emotional turmoil.

comment_text:
​​@@jeffjorczakI used to think it was Mark Twain too. Because the quote is often incorrectly attributed to Mark Twain and Abraham Lincoln, but neither of them actually said it. 
The most reliable source for the quote's origin is a 1907 book by Maurice Switzer, according to NPR. (National Public Radio).

And it's from the Bible actually, a paraphrase of Proverbs 17:28, which states, "Even fools are thought wise if they keep silent, and discerning if they hold their tongues".
author: @eyeswideopendevushka

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
This is not a Mark Twain or Abraham Lincoln quote. Though it is often incorrectly attributed to Twain and Lincoln, but neither of them actually said it. 
The most reliable source for the quote's origin is a 1907 book by Maurice Switzer, according to NPR. (National Public Radio).

It's from the Bible actually, a paraphrase of Proverbs 17:28, which states, "Even fools are thought wise if they keep silent, and discerning if they hold their tongues".
author: @eyeswideopendevushka

comment_text: There has never been a shotage of rude and/or passive-aggresive people on this planet. Just reading the comments here proves that. What there has been a shortage of is straightforward and effective advice on how to neutralize haters. Not until this professional negotiator decided to bless us with the benefit of his tried and true techniques on how to choose ones battles, not buy in and prevent haters from filling your ears with salt. The angry remain just that. While you move forward unscathed. Sound advice from a shrewd negotiator. I liken the rudeness of others to someone giving me an inappropriate gift that is quite simply "too much"  to accept. In which case you have no choice but to POLITELY give it back to them! Because you simply cannot accept it. But thank them just the same for their offering. Leaving them scratching their head in disbelief, because there is nowhere else for them to go with it... But to their next victim

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Hi! Great podcast! I heard you use "triggered" a few times and want to share something I learned recently as a mindfulness coach. There is a new word or mindset for this. Triggered implies it happens and we don't have agency as to our response. Much like pulling a trigger on a gun. When it happens, there is no stopping it. I learned it's healthier to think of it as being activated. You still have a response, but it doesn't imply what's done is done and I can be out of control. If I'm activated, I have permission to regulate my response. It also refers to what is happening now vs the "trigger" from the past. Interesting lesson.

comment_text:
I definitely like the word just. I find myself having to remove that word from my comments or when writing coz i overuse it so much. I just... like just. Lol. 
Its funny how many videos like these I watch. How much information I'm taking in online, on social media, on tv, in my day to day life. But theres no action behind it to make it stick. Just taking in the information without absorbing it. Everything recorded, but nothing is retained. 
I think I can at least remember to take the breath. Thats good advice. My mouth moves much faster than my thoughts get in order. I often find myself saying things that, I dont know why I said it, and I didnt really mean it. And didnt think it thru. Which feeds into my low self esteem because I'll think about that interaction after the fact, and just completely cringe at myself, and regret how I went about it ya know? Like...why did I say or do or act like that? I over apologize a lot...I guess I sorta feel like my existence is an inconvenience for others? And that people will be impatient, if I were to actually slow down enough so I can say my thoughts in the way and mannor I actually want to say them. Idk...this was a cool episode. Really kinda felt like I had a mirror up to myself throughout the video. Its a bit uncomfortable. But it brought some things I didnt quite realize about myself, to light... so thats always cool. 😊👍

comment_text: I ended a two year friendship because of the way the other person argued. It wasn't just the way they argued and their tactic (silent treatment), it was the indication of their character and I realised that this person expected others to kneel to them and would humiliate them. I ceased my interaction with a man because of one conversation during a first date which indicated their baseline attitude ("I don't believe in monogamy, it doesn't work etc etc" - he gave an entire monologue) and values. I agree with Jefferson, the more words it takes to say something, the red flag goes up with respect to truth. It's not always about the factual truth of what someone says, it's also about how much they lie to themselves or self-deny to justify a point. I don't want to be around people who live in their own delusion, because these types will gaslight you, alter truths, and try to make you look foolish over time.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I had a job many years back where I was tasked with approving or disapproving the quality of machinery construction. I had a detailed checklist that had to be followed to produce high quality standards. This machinery was shipped from the assembly dept to a production plant to be proofed before being shipped to the final manufacturing plant. All went well until I encountered two of the assemblers that had gone to another facility that used the same machine. What they saw was a poorly maintained machine. They cornered me asking why they had to be so precise when others were neglectful. I locked eyes with them with the appearance disbelief on my face but did not utter one word for a considerable length of time.  The silence was deafening until they asked why I got so upset. I never answered them verbally, my facial expression said all that needed to be said. They apologized and never approached me like that again and always did their jobs as expected. I kept the event confidential. We continued to work well together.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
I enjoyed this conversation very much and will likely listen again. I consider myself a good communicator and still I got a number of great tips! 
 That said, I offer the following feedback. At the end when you were promoting the book, I found it odd that you looked down at the desk the entire (lengthy) time you were talking and never held up the book so we could see the cover. You just kept looking down, flipping through the pages, talking. Very frustrating.

Another thing is something I find quite annoying, which I’ve wanted to comment on before and will do so now since this subject is on communication style. You have the tendency at times to almost cut off a guest by abruptly blurting out a question…like “Why?”…at the end of their comment, leaving no space after their last word before you shoot out the bullet. It feels more like an interrogation than an honest inquiry, and if I were on the receiving end it would have the effect of closing me down. I only noticed it once in this interview, but sometimes you do it multiple times in succession. As a result, I watch your show less than I would otherwise.

comment_text:
How to talk to people who are unable or unwilling to talk about anything other than small talk. The weather, what did you eat yesterday, what are you watching, gossip about other people etc. I find it very taxing to have these types of surface, pointless conversations. Even the ‘what are you watching’  can be discussed on a deeper level but some people are so adverse to the depth. 
For example, my mum asked what am I watching and I answered ‘I’m re-watching the walking dead, as it is a fascinating depiction of human nature’ to which I was met with a response that basically said ‘that’s a bit deep, don’t you want to watch something lighter like the great British bake off’ 
I’m afraid there’s only so much one can talk about sponge cake and icing before one’s brain starts to liquify and seep from one’s ears.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Thinking of someone as “disrespecting me” is already framed completely wrong. If they are not interacting with me on terms that are acceptable to me, then I am the one disrespecting MYSELF by engaging with them. So it’s 100% on me to disengage and cease to disrespect myself. I might offer them an extra opportunity, in that moment, to engage with me on my terms. But if they can’t or won’t, then it’s sayonara. 

If you are legally bound to deal with them for X amount of time, then an adaptation of some kind needs to be made for that BRIEF amount of time. But the main problem anyone has is self-disrespect.

The enneagram does a good job over doing some profiling and certain people come out emotion dominant (2,3 & 4s). These people are at a distinct disadvantage whereas someone who is mind-centric (5, 6 & 7) fall more into a cerebral approach - its more than clear Jeffrey is in this space (as am I). The point being is not as clear cut as an under-developed person. Its a function of their personality (which is fashioned over time and start forming around some primary injury that happened when young). video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: There's a lot more nuance to it than what's being discussed here. For example when it comes to confidence and being seen as a leader or expert. If you don't talk, you'll be overlooked. If you talk but add nothing, you'll be seen as a waste of space. If you ramble, you'll be seen as a bumbler and potentially incompetent. The trick is to speak, but be as concise and direct as possible, while actually adding something of substance to the conversation. Leave them wanting to know what else you can bring to the table if they ask you. But all that said, it needs to be done organically and not as a manipulation tactic.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
So many gems!  I’ll definitely have to watch this a few more times. 

Use less words to say more. Confidence is quiet.  

The more words you say the less truthful you sound. 

Your first word is your breath. 
Then slow down when you speak. 

Thank you instead of I’m sorry. 

Be direct. Fewer words. 

Say it with control
Say it with confidence
Say it to connect

Know what you want to talk about and know where you want to end up

I don’t need you to change your mind, I just need to let you know …

You don’t have to like it, you just have to understand. 

Don’t set out to win an argument. 
When you set out to win the argument, You will lose the relationship. 

Ask;  What am I missing?
Help me untie the knot.

If some one says something that came across rudely or hurtful ask
“Did you mean that to sound that way?”

If they insult you, 
Breathe
“I’m going to need you to repeat that”
or
“Can you repeat that?”

If you want to say no. Be a truth teller. Don’t be dishonest. Just say no. 

So much more.

comment_text: We've been married 31 years and have  had probably 5 or 6 arguments in total. We decided before marriage that we would communicate not fight. I almost always understand what they’re trying to say, but they sure don’t feel that way. I will try letting my breath be my first word and speaking evenly and calmly.
author: @toomanycooks4526

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I live with someone with ADHD who cuts me off every time I speak and reacts to my words without the intended context. It is frustrating and requires a lot more effort to communicate. video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: @@miccassady9450 For me, if I have to wait for someone to slowly finish their words my brain has already moved on after (usually) understanding what they were telling me. I can't then hear what they're saying because it took too long to get to their point when I already knew the point. I can't control how other people react to their circumstances. I can only react to my own circumstances. It is not my place to manage other people's emotions.

This hit hard.     Im 49 and realised i do what you describe , a while ago.     I paid to go to Gestallt Therapy , and the tools i gained were about being present.    This change in being  has given me room to speak more consciously, and remember to make a point of ACTIVELY LISTENING.    I still fuck up ,  usually at a bus stop with a stranger , I'll perhaps get carried away - and i don't catch on I'm doing it until 5, 10 +  mins in.  
 Then you spot the glazed eyes ,or hear the "must be getting on now, nice talking to you" exit in  polite northern English.    amd oHMy GOD i want to die 😢 its mortifying.
   I'm working on making myself reminders to take turns,  not jnterupt , wait for questions , not have to give every last detail and say one sentence at a time and to  REMEMBER , CONVERSATION IS A DANCE , before I strike up conversation. video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I used to work in a German company handling the top management. One of my Co workers was Thomas Pierline. He was responsible of launching a new IT system in the region, it was a big deal. Of course there were glitches and most of the middle age senior executives would bombard him with the most ridiculous but genuine complaints. He would look at each one of them without a hint of frustration or contempt, let everyone speak, gave that little sigh which was barely visible,  and once they finished, said,  'Gentlemen, I will help you but you need to let me know what you want to me to do. Shouting at me won't help me solve your problems. I am here to assist you.' The 25 year old me was so impressed by his calmness because those men in the boardroom could make or break his career in that instant but after he said that, the animosity dissipated in that room and everybody was almost careful when they said the next words. It was not so much what he said but how he said it. That's power.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Interestingly alot of what he is teaching I've learned through years if introspective learning.  Understanding that the person in front of you is another being who deserves respect, not because they did this or that or born into this type of life or that but because they exist.  In relationships if a conversation is between two egos, nothing positive will come from it.  If the conversation is between two people who show each other respect then there is an opening for understanding.  Another thing is that people respond from their filters, you don't know what's going on with them, but it's likely that it doesn't have anything to do with you.  So don't respond as if it's personal, this goes along way in your daily interactions.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
"Confident people have the urge to say nothing."

This is a ridiculous oversimplification. Is Jefferson Fisher here not confident because he is doing a 2-hour podcast?

Also, simply being quiet does not get you very far in business. In work places, you have to speak up. You have to make yourself heard and known. My 30 years of work experience, and watching social processes in the world (such as with politics), informs me that being quiet does not get you picked for leadership. When you're in a meeting with numerous people who all want attention to present their ideas, you have to make room for yourself. You have to speak up. You have to be heard. You can't just be the quiet kid in the back of class and get the job. Sorry.

"The people that are the most looked to are the people that say the least."

Nonsense. Does he have a study on this? Again, my experience tells me otherwise. It CAN be the case that quietER people are looked to because of their background, position of authority, and mental prowess, but I don't at all accept that people who say the least are "the most looked to." BS. If you don't say anything in most settings then you simply will not be heard and will not be considered.

comment_text:
Thank you for letting me know that you are a liar because claiming that everyone who uses the word honestly is a liar is a misrepresentation of the word used in our language.
I am from the south and if someone uses the word, honestly then they are actually indicating that they are no longer joking around and they are being serious in the moment about whatever subject is being discussed.
It is all context .
author: @ShopMom

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I have to disagree a little here.  My family is a dishonest, untrusting lot.  I have used the word "honestly" or "honest" when disbelieved, and I was telling the truth.  Also, my family was more than dysfunctional and said "always" (as in YOU always) and never (YOU never).  It has taken me 50 years to get to the point where I do not usually say always or never anymore, and if I do, I catch myself and correct "well, not *ALWAYS*".  Truth is very important to me, having grown up in an environment where I didn't know what was true and what wasn't.  Not everyone uses the word honestly (or any other number of words) to try to convince someone of a lie.  It could be because that person was taught that no one will believe them.

comment_text:
Some of this stuff can be effective, but only in specific circumstances. For example, talking slowly and taking pauses. This is effective when you have been asked a question, and the focus is on you and only you. When in a group setting, where people are jockeying for position in a conversation, there is no room for this. 

Power dynamics come into play here too. Where there are people higher up in a hierarchical system who are talking, fighting for position, moving from topic to topic, and leaving no room for you to enter, these techniques just don't work.

People use manipulative and toxic wordsmithing now more than ever in today’s society in order to get over on one another.

This issue continues to grow in our society, more and more as Capitalism pushes every person towards the edges of individualism and over that chasm.

If you look closely, you will start to see the death of communities they had previously worked together, Goodwill towards other people continues to be perverted for social clout, likes and subscribers on a video someone made about giving $100 to a homeless man.

The problem is that our society of people have been taught that the rules of “equivalent exchange“ favor, those who have the power and the money and so, those with all the power and money don’t have to pay as much for goods and services from those who are doing said services.

Due to the exchange rate being so one-sided on behalf of the entrepreneur/business owner, bigger and bigger gaps of social wealth disparity become more and more prevalent making the poor/lower/middle class, resentful of the upper and higher class people because they take advantage of everyone with little to know equivalent exchange.

The game has been rigged and it is time to use the skills that this man is teaching us in this video to take back the power from those who have squandered it from everyone and don’t want to relinquish that power.

It’s about damn time we start doing things for the betterment of the people around us and not specifically for the financial gains people get over others.

The fact that we are not a thriving country here in America because corporate entities have taken advantage of the people goes to show you that corruption and power our self-serving and if you don’t put the right people in those positions, they will continue to take away from the communities until there is nothing positive left

The fact of the matter is that people are not being raised from childhood to be good people, especially from the 90s and forward.

The problem has been and will continue to be the fact that those who are rich and powerful don’t want to share their wealth or power with those below them, they feel that they earned their place and should be allowed to dictate whatever other people do because they worked so hard to get to the position they have.

But they don’t ever ask the question of “do I really need this multi billion dollar mansion when there are people who don’t have homes, struggling to work 2 to 3 jobs while raising two children.

Compassion in this world is far and few between in our people of society.

Mean spirited selfishness, corruption of morals, and the unwillingness to look at oneself and realize that “I’m only helping myself and not others around me“ is a big issue

The problem is that our society has taught us all to prioritize “me“ and not prioritize “we”

The only way the human race survives and thrives is if we can get together with one another and help each other boost one another up to be the best that we can be for one another.

making a decision that will benefit everyone as a whole and not just tip the scales in one person‘s favor is what every single person in this world should be doing, but because of how we are raised by our societies, we’ve been taught to be individualists and not socialist.

When humans work together, we do a lot of great work, but when you put us all against each other to compete against one another, that’s why you start to see large gaps of disparities begin to form in our societies.

While I agree, John should not get more bread than Heather if John did not work as hard as Heather, the point is not to look at who worked harder than who, but to see that while John does work harder than Heather, Heather provides a different set of skills that helps John be able to work as hard as he does, and that both John and Heather both equally deserve the same amount of bread because they may do two different jobs, but without Heather doing her job that indirectly helps John do his, John cannot do his job as effectively, and I dare say much worse because Heather cannot apply her services.

You see everybody’s trying to get over on one another when we should be working on creating strong and healthy relationships where we all get what we need as a community together instead of having the lowest of our communities, go beg for scraps from our state and federal systems.

Things would change overnight if people looked at the issues with compassion and a mindset to change the status quo from the predatory systems that they are now to systems that benefit everyone and the community at large
author: @xdeadlyoverlordxstreaming

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Outstanding professionalism from both parties. Thank you Steven and Jefferson for this interview, supermassive value!!!!

As I like focusing on the actual conversation rather than taking notes, I put this episode into a podcast summarizer AI, here are the main take-aways if there are people like me.

Summary
Jefferson Fischer shares strategies for effective communication and conflict resolution, emphasizing composure, curiosity, and understanding in conversations.

Highlights
🕒 Pause for Impact: Taking 5-7 seconds of silence helps maintain composure in heated discussions.
🔄 Reflect with Questions: Asking others to repeat themselves gauges sincerity and encourages understanding.
🌱 Embrace Curiosity: Viewing arguments as opportunities for understanding promotes deeper connections.
📏 Balance Communication: Assertive communication respects oneself while avoiding rudeness to others.
💬 Power of Words: Choosing words wisely can significantly impact personal and professional relationships.
💡 Vulnerability Strengthens Bonds: Admitting flaws fosters trust and openness between communicators.
📖 Continuous Improvement: Effective communication is a skill that can be refined through practice and intention.

Key Insights 
🌊 The Overflow Analogy: Communication resembles two glasses of water; one must first empty its own beliefs to absorb others’ perspectives effectively. This highlights the importance of active listening and understanding before sharing opinions.
🔄 Understanding Triggers: Recognizing one’s emotional triggers can enhance conflict resolution. Emotional distance allows for reflection, facilitating calm and constructive discussions.
💪 Confidence and Composure: Maintaining control during conflicts through breathing techniques and assertiveness leads to more fruitful outcomes and portrays strength in communication.
🤝 Respect and Curiosity: Viewing arguments not as battles to win, but as pathways to understanding nurtures connections and leads to amicable resolutions.
🎭 Body Language Matters: Non-verbal cues significantly influence communication, especially in high-stakes environments, emphasizing the need for composed body language.
🚫 Avoid Over-Apologizing: Excessive apologies can undermine confidence and undermine communication effectiveness, thereby reducing respect in conversations.
🗣 Words Shape Futures: How we communicate today, especially with young ones, plays a critical role in shaping their perspectives and futures, emphasizing mindful communication practices.
author: @interpersonalshow

comment_text:
From my own experience and this being so similar to what I felt. She sounds like a few old CEO’s I’ve worked for as their Asst. Mine fed off of power, control, demeaning, making sure you knew your place, of flexing her Corp CEO muscle, and demeaning you in front of everyone. It’s so shocking, shaming, embarrassing, and bullying. I was really good at my job, but it had nothing to do with my performance. It was her negative and toxic energy that filled the room, and my nervous system stayed on high alert. She wanted me to be her emotional, mental, and psychological punching bag. 
It’s not you, and it wasn’t me…we didn’t cause it, we can’t change it, and we can’t cure it. 
But, what we CAN control…is our outlook, women can be so spiteful, and cause so much drama, so looking for other job openings, apply for them. No rush, just patiently waiting to see what’s out there. It gives you your dignity, your power, and control back, and gives you peace while you’re working with her now. You will know you made the right decision, to get yourself out of that environment that chips away at you slowly.  You will be able to sense/feel the positivity in the the new environment’s energy. You will realize how bad it really was on you as time passes. You will be able to enjoy yourself again, and have an environment that feeds you and not deplete you. I can  see in hindsight, that I had to experience the bad in order to recognize the good. In other words, you have to know what you don’t want in order to know what you do want.

However I felt that I had control.

comment_text: How can you take a pause when the other person never stops speaking? My spouse can continue a rant for 15-20 minutes, saying the same thing over & over, without stopping. Then expects me to incorporate what he said into my life. Like he is saying, “conversation over, now do it.” I usually end up tuning him out, the 2nd or 3rd time around saying the same criticism.  Makes it really difficult to pause & then say something that isn’t going to escalate the moment.  If I say nothing, it is worse because I am not listening & disrespecting him.

comment_text: I have a friend who is constantly playing devil’s advocate, always taking the side opposite me, never agreeing.  It’s as if she either has a problem seeing the other side of an argument, or she wants to feel superior, on the higher road than me.  I don’t enjoy being around her anymore.  I like to be agreed with.  Not only that, but she seems to have an idea of what the ideal mental stability is, and anyone who deviates from that is inferior.  You can’t show any shaky emotion about anything that happened in your life without her suggesting you talk to a professional.  I suppose she considers it “dirty laundry”.  I viewed it as being vulnerable, and showing that I could trust her.  What’s ironic is that she enjoys coaching Special Olympics.  It’s ok for them, but “normal” people know better, and should be perfect.

comment_text: All the information here is interesting and useful--in an American context.  As an American living in Japan, I can attest that the attitude that is presented here may work in N. America and Western Europe, but it is exactly what would lead to failure in some Asian contexts.  Be careful.  Aggressiveness and confident directness is a very culture specific thing.  What might make you more successful in a Western context may be the very thing that leads to failure in another.
