My sorry was the same situation only my work friend of 13 years became supervisor. I knew she was opinionated and didn't always treat me like i was intelligent but as long as we were on the same level I could separate from her when she would say something I didn't appreciate. I didn't know what a narcissist was until she became my supervisor. I had been with the company 18 years and had a good record and reputation. Now 2 years after she has become my manager, I am unhireable to other departments because I have been written up so many times and have  had many interactions with HR from my trying to get help and her using them to punish. I'm now learning what you have already known. Never react to their bait. Easier said than done but it has been effective at times.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I dislike hearing people use verbal fillers to excess, as many people do these days. 'Like', 'like',' like', is particularly obnoxious. So is 'you know?' after every sentence, or even inserted into the middle of sentences.  It is so distracting! I find myself counting how many times fillers are used instead of listening to what's being said. 'Really,' is another one I really hate! A few 'ers' or 'ums' are fine, if not used every couple of words.  I used to have to transcribe long interviews, and though I was allowed to leave all those fillers out, I made sure to transcribe each one so the interviewer would realize how they came across.
author: @joanie2shoes

comment_text:
When he said that he was a fifth-generation lawyer, everything that followed seemed irrelevant. This is exactly what transgenerational healthy relationships look like: you learn life skills before you turn 18. Ninety-nine percent of people don't know what you know, or they spend half of their lives learning what you had already acquired before you could even drive.
This is what most people don't realize is luck. He's not successful because he is lucky, he is successful because early in life had a good foundation to build on his career. Most people don't have -it is sad, but that's the reality.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Years ago when I was doing public speaking and training I learned as a woman that standing up straight, deepening my voice intentionally and slowing down.  No ums, no JUSTS.  I was asked to speak to the board of directors at a major corporation to teach safety practices.  They flew in from all over the world and I’d been invited to be one of two keynote speakers but internally I felt intimidated.  The other speaker was the head of the FBI who cracked the Rizzo kidnapping case .  He graciously asked me if I preferred to go first or if I wanted him to.  I told him after considering it that I’d like to go first because I really wanted to be able to listen well to his presentation and have mine behind me.  In very intimidating company I found I had their respect and attention.  After all I had been heard before and then invited to be there so the Director of Safety and Security thought I brought something to the table.  That was 1992.  Memorable confidence lesson.
author: @suzziezhills

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Years ago when I was doing public speaking and training I learned as a woman that standing up straight, deepening my voice intentionally and slowing down.  No ums, no JUSTS. The other speaker was the head of the FBI who cracked the Rizzo kidnapping case .  He graciously asked me if I preferred to go first or if I wanted him to.  I told him after considering it that I’d like to go first because I really wanted to be able to listen well to his presentation and have mine behind me.  In very intimidating company I found I had their respect and attention.  After all I had been heard before and then invited to be there so the Director of Safety and Security thought I brought something to the table.  That was 1992.  Memorable confidence lesson.  My mother was not a listener but my dad was as was his mother, my grandmother.  You have DNA but you also have choices about how you admire and want to learn from.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
The Word to Stop Saying:

"Just": Jefferson Fisher emphasizes that the word "just" weakens your statements, making you sound hesitant and less assertive. It's often used to minimize or downplay what you're saying (e.g., "I just wanted to check in"). Removing "just" makes your communication more direct and confident.
7 (or so) Steps to Handle Disrespect/Rudeness/Belittling:
The steps are more an amalgamation of how he handles insults/rudeness/belittling, using similar steps for each.

1.  5-7 Seconds of Silence: When someone says something offensive, pause for 5-7 seconds. This serves multiple purposes:

It calms you down (using a "conversational breath" technique described below).
It lets the other person hear their own words, potentially making them reconsider.
It shows their words aren't threatening to you.
Let your breath be the first word you say, using a conversational breath, breathe in through the nose and out.
Ask Them to Repeat:

2.  For direct insults: Say something like, "[Insult repeated]?" (e.g., "I'm an idiot?"). This forces them to double down or backpedal.
For belittling/condescending remarks: Ask a "question of intent," such as "Did you say that to upset me?" or "Did you mean for that to sound rude?" This forces them to acknowledge their intention.

3.  Let it Sit/Thank them/Question them:
After asking for them to repeat, depending on the situation, you can do a variety of things.

Insults: Say "Thank you", it shows them who they are.
Belittling remarks: Ask another questions, such as, ""How does it make you feel when you say that to me?", "I'm surprised you said that out loud", "That was rude.", or even ""That's below my standard for response."
Other steps/advice include:

4.  Slowing Down Your Words:
Slow your pace when speaking, it is more effective when you communicate.
Example:
Fast and emotional: "I already told you I'm not going to do that!"
Slow and controlled: "I... already... told you... I am not... going to do that."

5.  Say It With Control
Fisher's overarching point is controlling one's reactions, avoiding the fight-or-flight response, which usually occurs when in an argument.

6.  Say It With Confidence
Fisher notes confidence isn't something you have before, but is the outcome of doing assertive things. He states confidence is as assertive does, so you gain confidence by using your assertive voice.

7.  Say it to Connect
Have difficult conversations, be curious, find the framework.
Conversational frame example:

State what you want to talk about.
State how you want the conversation to end.
Get their buy-in ("Does that sound good?").
author: @idjr2654

comment_text: A big part of all of this, is to be intentional- to not take any bait. No matter what they say which is very difficult because naturally we take insults /disrespect personally and feel upset.  Taking that pause he suggests is excellent, remaining calm/removing ourselves from that bait, is more like becoming an observer rather than a participant. If you are an observer in a (manipulative) conversation it's much easier to remain in control and move the dialogue in a way that's actually useful.

comment_text:
My response to someone who says "you are ugly" would be to laugh, not because I am not ugly but because it is such a foolish thing to say to anyone, not worthy of hurt feelings. To be upset about an insult is to give more importance to that person than is warranted.

About child rearing; "more is caught than taught", the children will remember more what we do than hear what we say. We can teach good things but if we model unkind things they will do the unkind things. And, the Father is the primary resource for learning, he leads without trying, whatever the Father does will be emulated by the children. If the Father does not back up the Mother, then the children will learn to treat the Mother disrespectfully because of the Father's lack of support for her.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: A LOT of great stuff in here Thanks for sharing! In my opinion, there’s some advice in here that simply is not practical in corporate environments, or at least not in the way these skills were described. Yes, context matters - a lot. Saying people who always play devil’s advocate in convos are the least connected, or they want you to know how smart they are, I don’t agree with at all. Sometimes, there are people making decisions who simply don’t have the experience. By not speaking up, or making a convincing argument to explain to someone “why,” I don’t feel is a bad thing at all. By not speaking up could leads to more problems, mistakes, and further frustrations. Being overly confident could also be perceived as arrogance. These tools are very important in the right context. That’s my two cents.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: If i hear uptalk/upspeak and/or vocal fry in someone's voice, I immediately dismiss anything they have to say, even if it's to my benefit. The cultural upswing of asking "Right?" after every sentence is not far behind. As if validation is desperately needed for every statement. This way of communicating is at epidemic levels in the culture. It's reflective of the "everything is relative, I am certain of nothing, and I fear offending anyone in the slightest" way of reasoning and it's wholly unproductive.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: @@NatzTalkabsolutely! I was in an abusive relationship and I can honestly say that the bruises heal, but his words left a permanent imprint on me. For example, I used to be very fun and outgoing. Not afraid to be a little goofy and I’d always have those around me laughing. The other day I was with my Sunday school group and we were going around the room telling 3 facts that ppl don’t know and I mentioned that I’m a goofball/like to make people laugh and smile and one of the ladies laugh scoffed (not in a mean way) but she was like “you?! Goofy?! You are so quiet and shy!” And it just opened my eyes to how much my ex telling me constantly how stupid I am and how nobody likes me has me suppressing my personality and hiding myself in fear that people will judge me or say something mean. I never used to be like this! At home with my husband and kids I am always singing silly songs I made up making my husband and kids laugh and stuff like that. But no matter how hard I try, I just can’t convince myself to be myself outside of the comfort of home.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
I appreciate the thoughtful manner in which you explained what you've learned through your interactions with others, and are of the mind to impart this wisdom to as many people as possible. I'm definitely going to be taking the time to implement several of your suggestions in my communications with others. Starting today.
There is something you said that I am not so sure about though. When you spoke about, (and I'm paraphrasing here) "People who are the most confident being the ones who are able to effectively communicate, using the minimum amount of words, or better yet, none at all."
That's a tricky one. Because it's more about an efficient communicator. Which is good. No argument there.
But an insufficient communicator, like one who doesn't answer,  or responds with one, or two word responses, whilst omitting key information in an attempt to control the dynamic through withholding key information, or staying completely silent as a form of manipulative controlling behavior, and keep the other person in a state of confusion, or at a disadvantage of some sort.
Because I've been trying to find resolutions to situations with others I care about very much, who use that kind of manipulative control tactic to avoid accountability, and keep me in a "subordinate" position.
Which seems like something an effective/efficient/confident communicator wouldn't do. But rather someone who is very much the opposite. Although, I could be mistaken.

comment_text:
Thanks for your sensitivity as a teacher realizing that you were shaping impressionable minds. I have an older brother that I have always admired. He was president of the student body in Jr. high school (middle school today). He was in the National Honor Society, had a paper route and bought his own clothes, played intramural basketball etc. 
One teacher asked me why I was not like him. Out of respect for that teacher, I did not say what I was thinking (times were different back then) but I wondered why she would not let me be me instead of like my brother. She could not see what I would become by using the gifts and talents that the Lord created in me. I later was saved and born again and have lived a fruitful life. After that happened, I was called to be a bible teacher of children and adults. I believe that she meant well but her words had discouraged me back then. I learned not to use her approach but to use an approach that showed concern instead.

comment_text: ​@@marlenegold280I was fortunate enough that I had a high enough intelligence that I never needed to study and anything that I read or wrote I could retain so I excelled by grades but I was pre ADHD so because I was hyperactive and disruptive to others mostly because of boredom I had several teachers who idk if they just had enough experience to understand what was happening but they would either use me like a teacher aid handing out papers or helping other students or simply placing me in the rear of the room facing out the window but many times I would correct them if they misspoke or said something that contradicted what the book said and I would be treated poorly more often than not, which I didn't understand as a child but I figured out along the way but the few really good teachers I had kept me from becoming the person I was on a path to become, unfortunately when you grow up in a constant state of fight or flight where you never feel safe or loved probably because of the overactive side of it since I never sought treatment or diagnosis I can't even validate my opinion that I have ADHD but I also can say that I never used it as an excuse like I see so much and even with my own child I found myself trying to excuse or reinforcing their beliefs that they have a disadvantage which I found ways to get them to see that they were extremely exceptional at everything that they were interested in that they were not disabled but disinterested and they could easily control what they were interested in the biggest problem with public education is that it doesn't have a place for excellence and complex inabilities weather that is mental illness, mental retardation or the product of a poor child rearing like abuse or worse a parent who needs the child to be the parent which I have witnessed a couple times and thought I knew I had it poor but I couldn't imagine having to be the parent like seriously if your a single mother whose deeply depressed or whatever and you find your child making you food or doing things constantly to try and make you feel better, get some professional help and maybe if it's an option help from a relative or the biological father it's not worth the damage that your mental health can cause your child
author: @crazycraig1978

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: ​@@DrJudyASmithagreed I would rate myself as a fairly poor communicator as I have a predisposition for being right that probably stems from childhood traumas but was reinforced by having a very strong memory that has since become significantly less reliable. After watching this I have a much better understanding of why people always seemed to find me offputting, cocky, arrogant, when I never felt that was what I was, I know that there are many ways to skin a cat so to say and that most of the time there are multiple ways to solve a problem but I also had a religious upbringing and always believed that there is a right way to do things and a wrong way and I have always been vigilant to avoid intentionally doing things that I believe immoral which I thought was mostly why people thought I might think of myself as more important than I am or whatever, here I see that simple things that I never even considered might actually make other people feel cornered or attacked that because they were not "triggers" for me I was oblivious to them and I have plenty of my own personal "triggers" mostly connected to insecureties developed in childhood and the continued relationship with my father to this day I don't remember him ever once saying I love you, or I'm proud of you which I have even attempted to have a conversation about but fortunately I was blessed with a relationship with a woman who actually pointed out all the things that I rarely if ever even saw, she said his eyes would light up everytime he spoke of me and pointed out all the things that he did because he thought it was something I liked which I couldn't see because usually they were things that he liked that I had felt compelled to enjoy more because he enjoyed them and I was constantly seeking his approval. Given that my father and grandfather and great grandfather as far back as I could find have been career military men until my father who was medically discharged but all 6 of his brothers were enlisted and served, I think that maybe it's a byproduct or maybe an intent that perpetuates the soldier-warrior mindset, I experienced harsh discipline and grew up believing that you did as you were told and if you didn't there was literal hell to pay eternally but the more I learned about what our government actually has done around the world the more I questioned everything and I rebelled and spent many years in complete absence of my entire family other than communicating with my siblings occasionally and then my parents started having health issues and I was faced with the thoughts of losing them and never really knowing them and after several attempts actually came to forgiveness and maybe not understanding but acceptance that they did the best they could at the time I know that they have a much better relationship with my children than they ever had with me which I guess has made things easier for me but still difficult because I have done my best to be a better parent and have never uttered the phrase because I said so that I heard so much. I don't even remember where I started or where I was going with any of this but I'm glad I took the time to watch this podcast I have been a fan since the first time I saw him although I have only been online for about a year and a half because I really thought that it was a waste of life indulging in entertainment online, I haven't had cable television since the 90s and typically only ever watched movies and then my ex was big into Netflix and I started binging which I have to say was way better than waiting a week for the next episode I bet we watched Seinfeld 7 times and it was way better than I remembered just because you actually saw every episode and could see all the little things that you might have missed or forgotten I recommend it to everyone it might have been the best series ever mostly because they knew when to pull the plug because a lot of shows just keep trying and in the end usually are crap but she also got me to convert from my trusty flip phone to a smartphone which I have to say is not realistic for anyone who does manual labor but has proven it's worth while because it provides information at the flick of the finger that I used to have to study and retain and constantly update but I have noticed that I have a much harder time remembering things I rarely ever had a problem remembering people's names or where I knew them from and most of the time their phone number if I had ever used it now I can't even remember my own cell phone number without looking it up, I can remember some like my parents and even my childhood phone and address but new information seems to be very difficult to retain

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Public speaking is so important and these verbal fillers are killers - stop and take a breath and think. Then move on. Public Speaking Courses - Christopher Leadership Courses, I used to teach these workshops and I have changed so much and have actually spoken to speakers after their talk. I ask them if they are open to feedback on their talk, not so much on the content, more on the delivery, and each person has been so thankful. Offering feedback genuinely is a gift. One gentleman I spoke to suggested he NEVER have change or keys in his pockets - people hear that more than they hear your talk, very off putting. Lots of simple tips, make eye contact, smile, be genuine, breathe. Lots of things that this person in this podcast. What is the name of the book and the lawyer's name. I waited to hear his name. I have to cut down on my emails, cut the fluff. THANK YOU!

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
2:13:57 you're talking to your Son as if you are talking to yourself! Priceless!!! 💎💎💎
I was raised by a USMC Dad (1967-85) who had control/OCD issues. He spoke to our family like a Drill Sargent... that didn't work out so well for me or how I raised my son. 

I hope you do a podcast on how Dad's can confidently "securely" communicate with boy's. What it looks like to model emotional intelligence... regulation. 

I've just completed 3 yrs of EMDR for my untreated developmental trauma. For the 1st time in my life I actually feel self compassion. It took a lot of work to overcome the toxic shame, inner critic voices, trauma triggers/flashbacks... 4F Limbic brain response Fight, Flight...

Anyway, when you described the way you talk to your son... I got emotional with Joy ...my Son is now 22yrs old. For 20 of those yrs my inner critical voice was toxic like my father's voice. I didn't have the capacity to be self regulated. In fact, I expected my Son to regulate my feelings like my father modeled.

comment_text:
Hmmm sounds like a lot of great Christian principles advise if you ask me. 😊 See it below:

Proverbs 12:14 
 Wise words bring many benefits.

Proverbs 12:18 
The words of the reckless pierce like swords, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.

Proverbs 13:3
The one who guards his mouth preserves his life; the one who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.

Proverbs 15:1
A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.

Proverbs 15:2
The tongue of the wise commends knowledge, but the mouths of fools pour out folly.

Proverbs 15:4
A gentle tongue is a tree of life, but perverseness in it breaks the spirit.

Proverbs 15:28
The heart of the godly thinks carefully before speaking.

Proverbs 16:24
Gracious words are a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.

Proverbs 17:27 
He who restrains his words has knowledge,
And he who has a cool spirit is a man of understanding.

Proverbs 18:21
The tongue has the power of life and death, and those who love it will eat its fruit.

Proverbs 21:23
 Watch your tongue and keep your mouth shut, and you will stay out of trouble.

James 3:1-11

Controlling the Things We Say
3 My brothers and sisters, not many of you should be teachers. I say this because, as you know, we who teach will be judged more strictly than others.

2 We all make many mistakes. A person who never said anything wrong would be perfect. Someone like that would be able to control their whole body too. 3 We put bits into the mouths of horses to make them obey us. With these bits we can control their whole body. 4 It is the same with ships. A ship is very big, and it is pushed by strong winds. But a very small rudder controls that big ship. And the one who controls the rudder decides where the ship will go. It goes where he wants it to go. 5 It is the same with our tongue. It is a small part of the body, but it can boast about doing great things.

A big forest fire can be started with only a little flame. 6 The tongue is like a fire. It is a world of evil among the parts of our body. It spreads its evil through our whole body and starts a fire that influences all of life. It gets this fire from hell.

7 Humans have control over every kind of wild animal, bird, reptile, and fish, and they have controlled all these things. 8 But no one can control the tongue. It is wild and evil, full of deadly poison. 9 We use our tongues to praise our Lord and Father, but then we curse people who were created in God’s likeness. 10 These praises and curses come from the same mouth. My brothers and sisters, this should not happen. 11 Do good water and bad water flow from the same spring? Of course not.

comment_text:
This is the 2nd guest you had on that is "supposedly," an expert on conversation. I find it hilarious that they are men. Men, that essentially go on to say, that "Women speak," is all wrong. 
This Man is a lawyer, that helps people, try to win lawsuits. He also, is clearly an introvert. Believe it or not true extroverts, don't have to hire someone to teach them how to communicate. What he is not is a communication "expert." If he was an expert, he would know that in many cultures, his long pauses, (which by the way, he thinks is oh so clever,) is seen by many cultures as hiding something, and/or lying. He also does not understand women speak. But, hey there are also some women that don't understand women speak.

I am not saying, there is not a time to pause to think about a question, either how you are going to answer it or if you want to make sure you can answer in a way, that a person understands your answer. 
Believe it or not, there are people that don't analyzes everything that comes out of their mouth "all the time," because they are not that insecure or all that worried about appearances or offense. 

I notice the people on here that are sooooo impressed with him, do not have good communication skills or loveeeeee for someone to have that undivided attention look on their face. I find that annoying and phony as hell. Why? Cause it is phony. If I just meet you. You don't know me well enough, to look at me that way. Phony as all hell.

comment_text:
26:13 host = "what is my Assertive voice?
This reminds of The Adult Voice, one of 3 Voices identified in Transactional Analysis ( TA ), a theory and method of therapy developed by Eric Berne, analyzes social interactions (or "transactions") to understand behavior by examining the communicator's ego state (Parent, Adult, or Child). 

This healthy and Assertive "Adult Voice" is the basis used by Dr Thomas Phelan's discipline communication method for parents to their children. 123 Magic is honestly phenomenal if one understands this video's guest speaker's points of confident assertive communication. 

Speaking as he explains is self respectful really. And respectful of the recipient.  All around respect and calm.

comment_text: re: how to say no, about the 2 hour mark. my Dad always told me I did not have to justify a No answer. No thank you, i can't make it this time, and add appreciation for the offer.  No need to make up excuse, it's no one's business, if they push for more info, and you give them more details, you are feeding their entitlement, and risk insulting them  by telling them what you find more important than they are, and likely they will take it as a challenge, or  they will instantly take it upon themselves to solve the problem /obstacle as if you desired their help.   if in fact, you truly have an obstacle and would really like to find a way around it, that's the only time you might bother with an explanation , and  work together to see if you can juggle things around, maybe they have an idea of how to help, otherwise, its no one's business why you say no.

comment_text:
First time viewer and only 2:04 minutes in and you managed to catch my full attention which is a rarity. I believe humanity must learn how to communicate with each other, we have lost that art over the last 4 decades. We listen to respond not to hear what someone is trying to communicate to us. We respond to WIN the conversation. Conversation shouldn't be a sport on who wins. It is vital to communicate and be understood. I also believe humanity would benefit from teaching society about the 16 different personality types and how to interact and communicate with each type. Many disagreements stem from misunderstandings. Understanding a person personality type would stop a lot of misunderstandings.

Edit
The most important video I have ever watched. Thank You

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
The unspoken language, come always before, the word that is spoken, which tells more than the spoken word.. Also your word belongs to you, and nobody Else. So it is very important that before a conversation, there is a moment of silence, that everyone involved can stop and think about what needs to be said, without insulting, hurting, or angering anyone who is involved..  We know that words effects matter, thats why we call it spelling, because words have power like a spell.. So be very careful about what you say....
What is more important, is listening to listen, and not listen to reply.. because if your listening with the intent to reply, your attention is by the reply and not listening... You really have to put yourself and all your wants, and needs on the side, and step into that person's skin, stand in their shoes, try to feel how they feel. You yourself for the time you listen are just not important, only the speaker, until it's you time to speak... Then no misunderstandings can happen, no one gets hurt, and the people know, that there be a good outcome in the conversation..... Remember your word belongs to you ......

comment_text: Absolute beautiful conversation. I, as a Mexican who speaks Spanish and lives in new Zealand, realized that the more I dominate my English, the easier it is for me to navigate my own reality, by being able to truly express myself and get what I really want and have deeper and more meaningful relationships with people that surround me. How can you be able to get what you want, if your vocabulary is limited? Even in your own language. The more words you know, the further you can go. Thank you for this refreshing conversation.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
@toniannbarandon-o1j
While I agree that it doesn’t mean other ppl don’t use these words, once you acknowledge that then these two words can no longer be singled out as “identifiers” of liars/whatever. I.e. what he said about these two words becomes meaningless. 
As for “weaponizing” — lots of other words are weaponized much more than these two. In fact, good liars are much more subtle and cunning. In my personal experience, I have my share of lies said, even if white and all, and I never needed to “weaponize” those two words. 
In short, what he said about never and always — is pointless and potentially dangerously misleading, because it’s untrue

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: At 2:02:15 about verbal fillers, what came to my mind is  the Toastmasters organization. Attending meetings helps train you to speak without these fillers as they are tracked. Feedback helps encourage you to use pauses to aid in providing your message effectively. Highly recommend it as a Distinguished Toastmaster myself 😅. Over my 10 years in the program, I found that the Most frequently used fillers are "like", "um", "and" & finally "so". Mine was always "so". I struggle focusing when I listen to someone who wastes pause or process time on filler words 😊. It is similar to a "but" because fillers can negate the value of the spoken works prior. ❤ Great interview!!

comment_text: Bruce Lee "In order to taste my cup of water, you must first empty your cup. My friend, drop all of your preconceived and fixed ideas and be neutral. Do you know why this cup is useful? Because it is empty." Of course Bruce Lee was talking about teaching someone how to fight that was stuck in the mindset of "fixed positions" but it can be used in many avenues in life like communication  So if we apply it to talking to someone who is defensive or confrontational it may be translated like this: Be open to what others have to say, not to be pursued but to better understand them and where they're coming from.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
@@BruceLee-fd7uw Please do not cast even a moment of doubt.  Yes, he was indeed standing there, on the wall of his raised planter bed, with his mouth hanging open.  This was a rarity, because he was prone to spew a tirade of foul words from his mouth.  If my little cattle dog could talk, she’d confirm it, as I had her on lead, against my leg, while this happened.  I could feel the low rumble growl coming from her as she was ready to protect me if he came over the fence separating our properties.  BTW - it was one of those ‘good neighbor’ 4-foot, powder coated vertical metal post-and-rail fences required by our city.

Some additional ‘history’ on this guy……He moved into his house 4 months before ours was ready for occupancy.  We bought this house because a job transfer landed us here, over 1,300 miles from our original home.  We worked with the builder to customize the house (I had been in the building trades), keeping in touch via FaceTime, as well as visits by my husband when he was in town for business.  The construction manager had to run the guy off our property after it was discovered that he was routinely entering the house, telling the trades (tile setters, finish carpenters, plumbers, etc) that he was OUR real estate agent, and he needed to take photographs of the progress for us!  This guy knew exactly where I’d designed a hidden-in-plain sight area for a safe, where security system motion sensors were located, and he was particularly interested in our entire ‘Smart House’ system.  He was caught by the construction manager and warned the next time, he’d be arrested for trespass.

Then, about 2 weekends prior to us taking possession (we’d been in town for about a month, routinely visiting the job site), the neighbor trenched from his property to ours, then trenched a line about the full length of our property ON OUR PROPERTY.  He set PVC pipe into the trenches, connecting his house gutter downspouts, and then he sawed off the base of our downspouts, connecting everything together, and buried the whole works.  One end of his ‘system’ daylighted through a white shower drain into our front yard, and the other end daylighted into our back yard, running downhill to a park behind us.  We weren’t there when he’d trenched and installed it that weekend, and neither was the builder.  He was furious!  Wrong materials, with some joints held together with duct tape.  The neighbor had destroyed our property grading, which would have voided our warranty.  Pipes close to the surface, which would cause freezing in the winter.  No clean-outs.  Builder gave him 3 days to dig up and remove everything, and neighbor was required to pay for the regrading of the land, and replacement of our gutter downspouts.  We certainly didn’t have an agreement with the neighbor to install this mess, let alone allow him to drain his rainwater runoff onto our property.  He refused to dig it up, so the builder ordered his team to “obliterate it”.  This delayed our move-in, as the property grade had to be recertified by a county inspector.  This was our introduction to over 2 years of sheer terror with the deranged Neighbor from Hell (we referred to him as our NFH).

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Some really good advice here but I've found some of the stuff he offers doesn't work very well.  It might for him but it doesn't for me because it comes off sounding awkward.  Honestly, MOST of his advice is outstanding so use that.  BUT if you find some of it isn't working as you expected or hoped, analyze that.  It might be your delivery, you might be making assumptions when you use a certain technique or it might not work for you.  There's another book called Crucial Conversations that I've also found to be REALLY helpful.  It helps you recognize when you're in a crucial conversation or when it's flipped from being casual to crucial....which often can happen in a nano-second so it's important to recognize when it has flipped.   Keep in mind, you could be well versed on all of these techniques and still have conversations blow up on you and/or not go the way you had hoped they would or expected they would.  WHY? Because we're all humans and sometimes we do really strange things.

13:32 Double Inhale by the Andrew Huberman Lab

5 minutes once a day
Double inhale through the nose followed by lungs empty with a rather passive exhale out the mouth.

That 2nd inhale after the 1st big long inhale through the nose is really important. It makes sure that all the collapsed abiola the lungs totally snap open. 

Then the exhale offloads a lot of carbon dioxide.

What Andrew Huberlin lab found was that the Double Inhale led to the greatest improvements in mood Around the Clock not just around the practice or during the practice as well as lowered resting heart rate improvements in sleep Etc…
      Then the exhale offloads a lot of carbon dioxide.

What Andrew Huberlin lab found was that the Cyclic Sign led to the greatest improvements in mood Around the Clock not just around the practice or during the practice as well as lowered resting heart rate improvements in sleep Etc…

59:04 mins
https://youtu.be/GVRDGQhoEYQ?si=BVi-6QnM03BulA1d


Meditation just sitting no instructions about how to breathe. Just focusing on um closing their eyes and focusing on focusing. 

Box Breathing. 
Inhale, 
hold, 
exhale 
hold, 
for equal durations the duration of each of those inhales. 
The holds was set by their carbon dioxide tolerance. Somewhere between (3 to 8) seconds depending on how well they regulate carbon dioxide.



Cyclic Hyperventilation which is a lot like Tumo AKA Wim Hof-ish breathing different than Wim Hof breathing so this would be so 

Very active inhales and exhales every 25 cycles of inhale exhale. 
Then 1 cycle long exhale hold lungs empty 15 to 30 seconds then repeat 
For a total of (x3) cycles

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
This was eye-opening. Here are few things that completely changed the way I communicate:
1. I stopped overexplaining myself. Confidence isn't about how much you say, but how clearly you say it
2. I read all books on Mindbloomery and implemented all their lessons into my life
3. I cut filler words that made me sound unsure. No more "sorry, but...", or "I think...". Now I just say what I mean with big confidence
4. A book "Power of Assertiveness: Unlock Your Potential" completely shifted how I express myself, set boundaries, and handle tough conversations. It's also a lot harder to get manipulated when you have proper tools
5. I started pausing before I speak. A well-placed silence is far more powerful than nervous chatter all the time

The main point is that if you take care of yourself, like physically, mentally, emotionally... people will notice that. And the way you walk, speak, and even make eye contact speaks louder than words
author: @niklaschristen6077

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: ❤ Same. I have been practicing the start with a breath thing. It actually puts you in that future spot "tomorrow" when you know the higher road to take, right now. I'm not very good at actually doing the right thing now, yet, but it makes a huge difference in the moment - I get the dialog mentally of the correct direction, even if I still wanna go off the tracks lol I at least saw the better path now, and like just a couple times I've actually been able to take the better path where I retained control of the conversation... And boy does it feel GOOD. That bitter back biting comment is still there tugging on your vocal chords but just let it stay there and you'll see it within just a few seconds. They'll storm off, they'll go off worse, they'll do even worse things that reveals they were trying to take your control and they didn't and now they know it and they know you know it. Plus it leaves the door open for them to come back in a different context next time.
author: @TruthQuestian78

Even if it was the night before it’s crazy making.

comment_text: I used to be that way.  But mostly 8-24 hours later. Simply PRACTICE-- DARING yourself to say something now. Then you can review it, and the word-choice and development of thoughts can ONLY happen in your private mind in your spare time.. The MORE OFTEN you speak up, speak out against what is wrong, when you FEEEL this power urging you to stop the madness,,,,THE MORE EASILY you will channel this from God. You will SWIFTLY transform your truth-relaying from intimidated compulsion to SELF-TRUSTING BOLDNESS and higher trust, that this did not only come from you-- it is divine

comment_text: Yes, I do too, I think it's the shock of an unexpected "attack" on me, often from a friend or family member,  and by the time you've gathered your wits, the moment has gone. Now I try and buy myself time, by saying things like " I can't talk now-then say why"   then I can sometimes find a good solution/ comeback

comment_text: Don't let your emotions get too high in the first place, so you don't need 24-48 hours to recover! Stress has a direct effect on your brain and cortisol levels, depending on how well you can handle it. Don't push back so you can't be pushed over! Give yourself some space, take a breath! Be aware of what triggers you and have the awareness to not let the fire or heat start in the first place! Be wise and authentic!

comment_text: You never said the wrong thing unless you assumed it wrong. The brain is like a computer, and a computer never gives the wrong answer. Stop doubting yourself, and your answers will always be right, even if others "think" It's wrong. If a computer had a personality, you would considered it arrogant because it would say, "I am never wrong "

comment_text:
I used to have the same problem until I learned to be calmer and more peaceful… I also worked on my personal confidence through understanding my personal boundaries and respecting myself first…

Once I did that , anxiety over conflict that shuts down my brain went away.

If you’re not knowing what to say , it means you are definitely in fight or flight mode already and you don’t realize it….

Deep breaths and reminding yourself, it’s OK to disagree with someone really helps a lot

comment_text:
Sometimes  , someone  brings in an argument  that  completely  distabilised  you.  Ex: The man  living  under my flat  accused  me  of  waking  up  " his  wife "   in the evening when  knocking on the door . Saying that he was having a  big smile. The problem  is  that   it was the  first  time in the last  5  years  I heard of a  woman in his  apartment . But ,  every  night , at  4  in the morning , I  could hear  him  having sex  with a  man  for  the last  5 years. I was  so flabergasted  I  lost  the argument.
                    My  error  ? Assuming he would  say the  truth   about  his noise  nuisance  with his  new  woofer .

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: This is called Delayed processing. For a lot of people (typically nuerodivirgent people) it's common and there's nothing we can do about it. Sometimes u process what is being said to u right away and can think of the response. Other times it takes time for ur brain to actually process all the information to be able to answer the way u would truly want to. I don't know all the scientific data behind this I just know it can be frustrating

comment_text:
It's not just insecure people who start rushing through conversations and get emotional. It's oftentimes people whose boundaries have been overstepped countless times in spite of them communicating them  c l e a r l y.
And it's not just insecure people who use a lot of fillers ("like", "you know", "just", ...) and subjunctives. Women in general tend to use them more frequently as those features make conversations appear less direct (or aggressive). At least that's what linguists found in gender studies

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
I was about to suggest singing as well.

Does anyone know Gareth Gates? He auditioned for Britain's Idunnowhat. His first audition, when he had to introduce himself, was so interesting. He could barely speak his name without a stutter. But he sang like an angel. 😊 
It's all about breathing and controlling the diaphragm.

But, hell, I also highly recommend hypnosis therapy. It's so effective with phobias. And I guess a stutter is something similar. An innate fear of rejection/ abandonment. My brother developed a stutter at a very young age. We had an abusive father who used to beat him up because he was too sensitive for a boy. The stutter slowly vanished after our dear papa left his final farewell. 
Long story short: Let a hipnosis therapist find your inner child's deepest insecurity and you'll most likely see a great improvement in no time. Don't fall for quack docs though. 


Good  luck on your journey. ❤ Happy healing
author: @kasijune88

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
​@@TeachLearnDo that question grabbed my attention beyond a thumbs up as I did hypnosis work 30 years ago with a stutterer of  35 years. The single session we had, led to him sharing a vision of himself as a newborn, he needed a medical treatment in the next 24 hrs, to stay alive, but the medical personnel were missing it. His knowing self, stuck in newborn limitations of not able to speak, was a negative experience he got stuck in. He had the knowledge, but couldn't speak up. The hospital figured out what he needed in time that he did live, but down to the wire. We did a release process. He stopped stuttering immediately. He moved to another country a few days later. I found out a few years later from a mutual acquaintance he stopped stuttering completely for 4 days. Normally a 2nd session would've happened before 4 days. 
So yes have you tried hypnosis is a very valid conversation.
All the best to us, in our choices.

comment_text: at around 1:24:00 when he made the texting while driving explanation, i disagree. I did text once in my life while driving(actually it was more like fondling my phone for maps) and had a (luckily minor) accident. Since that day I don't text or touch my phone while driving, and i'd also give a quick response with using the word never. Allthough im not american and not a native english speaker(but almost fluent) the issue here is, if people take this as their to go way to make judgements about people, I'd look like a liar from that moment on. What i want to point out here is, yes alot of those things are helpful, but some shouldn't be taken as an all out solution to human interaction, otherwise you might end up distrusting honest people, who just do not fall in the same behavioural category as most people.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Steven brings up a good question regarding Jefferson's approach to dealing with rude or belittling comments. When there is a large gap in authority between yourself and the rude person, you cannot easily impose boundaries without potential for negative consequences. 

The strategy outlined here where Jefferson encourages people to question whether the statement was intended to be hurtful, rude, etc. could easily get someone fired if used on their rude boss. Maybe it is time to find another job, but there is some risk in using this tactic.

To be clear, the information presented by Jefferson seems fantastic, but I feel like Steven's question about the context of those situations was a bit glossed over. It is a very important distinction to make

comment_text:
For sure! Here are some tips to help you improve your speaking skills:

1. Practice Regularly: The more you speak, the more comfortable you'll become. Try talking in front of a mirror or recording yourself.

2. Know Your Material: Whether it's a speech or a casual chat, being knowledgeable about what you're talking about boosts your confidence.

3. Slow Down: Speaking too fast can make you hard to understand. Take your time and articulate your words clearly.

4. Use Body Language: Non-verbal cues can enhance your message. Gestures and facial expressions can make your speech more engaging.

5. Get Feedback: Ask friends or family for their thoughts on your speaking style. Constructive criticism can help you improve.

6. Join a Group: Consider joining a local speaking club like Toastmasters. It's a great way to practice in a supportive environment.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: I think this guy REALLY underplays nonverbal facial expressions. For instance, if you take a moment to think about someone's question, but you just blankly stare at them for a couple of seconds, that's very disconcerting. However, if you look away for a second, change your face to convey "hmm," then answer the question, it looks like you thought about it. There are people who will not pick up on that and will just start doing the blank stare while they basically count "3,2,1" in their head.
author: @bronzey01

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
To win an argument ofte times means, you wil be seen as an oponent, an enemy, instead a genuine friend.
Combativeness is seen in battle.
To win. To eradicate.
Real positive communication, where 2 people or more are involved needs to be done in a very non manipulative, non toxic, combative way to resolve something.
The energy that someone has around him/her in an argument should feel safe and not heated, aka combat vibes.
The other sense it and is hurt, mistrust your genuine intentions.
People have that instinct.
Marriages also fail in this context.
Children grow up feeling not connected and rather in a battlefield, instead a loving, caring home.
The internal damage is done.

Read John Gottman books.

He made a study where he predicted divorce, based on how people communicated and their use of body language.
Very interresting study.
Also how to avoid divorce.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
I find that very difficult in my work.
There are a lot of bad decisions being made by people who have no idea about these topics, but they are in positions of power.
As did happen in a recent meeting. 
I tried to phrase everything in a positive and solution-driven manner, as did my colleagues (we coached each other before the meeting). But no matter the approach, there is always an executive who has already made up their mind, even though they have no objective arguments. At least none they could provide. 
Now this leaves me in a position where I have to follow a process that I know doesn't work in the given context. And this has already happened to me multiple times.
Because of the previous experiences, I also know that the blame for the failure will be put on me and the people around me.
We're the ones who know how to solve the issues, but we're not allowed to implement the necessary methods.
I am unsure if I want to save the relationships with these people (meaning the executives).
Maybe sometimes it's better to win the argument than saving a relationship. Thinking about it, I would not want my lawyer to have the mindset of putting relationships above winning arguments. 
"Well, you're in jail now for something you did not do, but at least they like you!" 
I still have 40 minutes left for this podcast, maybe there'll be more insights.^^

To be clear: I like the advice given in the podcast here. I just want to make my point that there are always exceptions to each rule and one has to know which method to use based on the current context.
author: @Fanmade1b

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!

comment_text: You may not lose the relationship straight away. It's not immediate. In a marriage/romantic/intimate relationship, it becomes gradual. People usually stay in marriages, because of kids or financial reasons due to the cost of the divorce, but the person has mentally and intimately checked out of the marriage. That's the other reason many affairs occur. It takes two. The person who always sets out to win each argument, and in the course of that uses humiliation and shame or induces those things in their partner, will lose the essence of the relationship with the other, and the other, not doing anything about it, remaining in that dynamic, also contributes to the loss of the relationship.
author: @sojourner22-n7s

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: @@TheTreeOctopus it depends. It's not the actual issue in the argument that causes it, it's the tactics. If you use shame, belittlment and humiliation to win an argument, which is what happens in most marriages for example, then people get drained over time. it's not about worth, it's about whether you make the other person feel little self worth over time that's the issue. For a relationship to be worth anything, both people have to be aware of the other, have self awareness and not resort to cheap manipulative tactics.

Ego has nothing to do with it.
If you're in a relationship and can't communicate openly and honestly, without the threat of them leaving, then it's a relationship founded on game playing and dishonesty. You are both much better off alone, with the chance to meet someone who shares similar traits and values.

comment_text:
​​​@@alakbar7870 what you do not understand about toxic is they are gonna get upset regardless. They are the forever triggered. When dealing with toxic you have to be in control of you not them. They are always out of control and they want you to match their energy so they can use that against you. In no way shape or form are you stooping to their level by pausing, because they are rapid fire people who will talk over you and can't even fathom pausing themselves. You are already way above their level. You just gotta stay there, on your own level, not let them drag you down to theirs. They are not upset that you paused they are upset about you not being upset yet. Know your animal. Know what you are dealing with. The more upset they get simply tells you, you are succeeding at keeping your own composure. Once you know, you know. I get why this person sees them getting upset as bonus. It is hilarious to watch. They will go through a rolidex of tactics. You can literally watch them desperately flip through it in their mind. Having a kaniption the whole time. And all you did was stand with your foot in the mud going, "No. Nope, Not gonna happen. Wear yourself out hammering away at the mountain, it's not moving."  They have no shame and will throw a hissy fit right in front of you. It is flat out pathetic. And that fit is not about you or what you are doing. It's about them not getting what they want. And what they want is to trigger you. And they are gonna act this way regardless because they are children and do not know how to get anything without throwing a two year old baby fit.
The only reason why they ever succeed with these tactics is because people just don't want to deal with conflict and give in trying to keep the peace. But no matter which way you go, give in or don't they are constantly gonna try to cause conflict and chaos to manipulate you, and will throw these fits. Giving in does not make it go away. Damned if you do, damned if you don't. You might as well accept that fact, choose your battles wisely, and calmly stand on business.

comment_text:
I've always been a safe space and listening ear for my children. 
I've always been their safety net, even now as adults. 
I gave them the tools to try to problem solve and to use me for assistance in finding a solution for their dilemma.  
They still come to me with their problems to help iron out the creases and find a solution.  

My son even asked me for my approval to ask his now fiancée to marry him.
I love her and gave my full blessing.

@catherines7553  Mine are grown adults now and view me as their safety net, knowing they can strike out in life and have a safe haven and listening ear, a place to decompress if it goes pear shaped.  
I get a cards from them on both mother's day and father's day. 
I've been both all their lives since their father thought drink, gambling and loose women were more important than them, at a very young age.

Stick with it and you'll have their respect for ever.b

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text: Just got done on another reply about this one - it works! I'm not very good at taking the higher path yet, but I can at least see it now, instead of hours or days later. It's practice man, and it's actually gotten me through a tough spot a couple times now where I kept control... Within seconds it was apparent that they suddenly know and try harder, which makes it easier to hold your position because now they are amplifying their lack of control... And what really gets them is that they will know you know now. They might not realize it the first time but it'll definitely sink in on the second conversation like that... And the look on their face when it happens, priceless yet at the same time you're leaving the door open for them to try again in a better way.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
The key is to make the distinction between facts and an opinion. 
Facts are objective and based on proof. Opinions are subjective and based on personal views coloured by one's own experiences .
When responding to someone's opinion it is important to ask questions like why do think this, what happened to make you see it this way, etc. instead of telling people they are wrong because they are not. An opinion is subjective and therefore is neither right nor wrong.

Now when people don't want to accept facts, it is often due to cognitive dissonance. This might often lead to irrational choices and actions.
author: @machteldvdb1185

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Communication is an art, and not everyone is an artist.

I meet very few people who find using the right kind of language important. 
My experience is that most people are not aware of how important and powerful the use of language is.
What words you use and where in a sentence you put them really matters.
How you speak and what you say will make the difference between having a constructive conversation or discussion and having a getting out of proportion argument.
However, in my opinion, communication is not only knowing how to speak and what to say. It is also about how to listen.
It is my experience that most people hear to react instead of listening to understand.

Also it is important to stay on topic and not to become personal, meaning playing the ball, not the individual.
author: @machteldvdb1185

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
@msv9637 , what I wrote in regards to communication applies to interactions with people in everyday life. 

If I understand correctly, this guest is not a litigator in court but a mediator.
A litigator argues his client's case in court, whereas a mediator's specialty is negotiations. He helps the opposing parties find a solution to their problem/conflict out of court. He does not judge, nor is there a judge present.

I think when this gentleman is talking about leaders, he's referring to people being a leader in general. Some people are loners, some people are followers, and some people are born leaders. The latter doesn't necessarily  mean that they are running a country.
MLK was a leader, Ghandi was a leader, Lech Walesa was a leader. He's a working man who created the first union in a communist country and later became president of Poland.
People who set up protest marches are leaders.
What I'm trying to say is that real leaders come in all shapes and forms.
It's not because someone is the president of a country, that he/she is a leader.
A real al leader's goal is not self-serving. It is to be of service.
author: @machteldvdb1185

comment_text:
The data suggests that by asking for likes and subscriptions, it increases the likelihood of getting them. If it didn’t help, they wouldn’t say it. There is a reason why every content creator inserts a verbal, and often visual, reminder to like/sub/comment/share. It’s because it does increase those metrics when you ask. 

Something, something, reciprocity, something, human psychology… 
It may be cringe for some, but it does work for many others.

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
MY TAKEAWAYS 
- Effective Communication: Jefferson Fisher, a trial attorney, emphasizes the power of words and how they can change outcomes in conflicts and relationships. He teaches how to argue less and say more to preserve relationships.

- Handling Disrespect: Instead of reacting aggressively to disrespect, use silence (5-7 seconds), ask the person to repeat what they said, and maintain control. This technique disarms the other person and shows confidence.

- The Power of Pausing: Pausing before responding, especially in arguments, helps you stay calm, think clearly, and respond more effectively. It also makes you appear more thoughtful and trustworthy.

- Avoiding Weak Language: Words like "just," "maybe," and "I think" can make you sound uncertain or weak. Replace them with confident, direct language to sound more assertive.

- Saying No with Confidence: When declining requests, be direct and kind. Avoid over-explaining or making excuses. Start with "no" and express gratitude to soften the blow.

- Body Language and Trust: In high-stakes situations (e.g., courtrooms), body language matters. Staying calm and composed builds trust, while emotional reactions can harm credibility.

- Dealing with Liars: Liars often use extreme language (e.g., "never," "always") and may become uncomfortable with silence. Use pauses and ask clarifying questions to reveal inconsistencies.

- Small Talk Mastery: Ask open-ended questions (how, what, when) to engage others in conversation. Focus on their interests and future plans rather than past events.

- Setting Boundaries: Be honest and direct when setting boundaries. Avoid over-apologizing or giving unnecessary explanations. Kindness and clarity are key.

- Impact on Future Generations: How you communicate with your children shapes their future communication patterns. Create a safe space for them to express themselves and model healthy conflict resolution.

- Self-Awareness: Recognize your triggers and emotional responses. Being aware of your communication habits allows you to improve and handle difficult conversations better.

- The Power of Silence: Silence can be a powerful tool in conversations. It forces the other person to reflect on their words and can reveal their true intentions.

- Avoiding Filler Words: Eliminate verbal fillers like "um" and "like" to sound more confident and effective, especially in formal settings.

-Kindness and Respect: Treating others with kindness, even in difficult situations, can disarm negativity and make you feel more in control.

- Continuous Improvement: Communication is a skill that can always be improved. Focus on small changes, like removing unnecessary words or practicing active listening, to become a better communicator. 🙏🙏

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!
comment_text:
Bollocks! It's 2 hours, and 17 minutes long, you teased all the tips in the beginning, and I thought, this looks really interesting, and it surely is, but it's not "entertainmenment", it requires depth of thought and self reflection/pondering. I don't think most movies are that long, (movies being engineered to suck you in attention-wise, hence why we can sit through a harry potter marathon all day). I figured out from learning stuff on YouTube tutorials, (like, say, photography, what certain features reference and how to use them) and come to the conclusion that the brain can (generally speaking) retain up to about 7 to 9 minutes per session of simple, direct, bullshit-free/waffle-free learning before the brain starts to resist and buffer, goes to commercials, comes back disgruntled, thinking, "what the fuck have you been waffling on about for the last 45 minutes?! I clicked your vid to learn about "why you should use 'back-button focus' and you've told me fuck-all of any use other than bragging about yourself, and just straight fucking waffling, and showing off your shitty editing. Twat!" 52 minutes to NOT say what "photo genius" DOES in 7 minutes!

Don't get me wrong, I'm not knocking your videos, there's philosophy, psychology, and life-changing practical applications to be gleaned from it. I see you have different tips sections, "how to say no" how to spot a liar" "how to reply to snarkiness" or whatever, great, but if you broke them down into more digestible portions it would be easier to extract and absorb the relevant content, and other sections would be easier to watch as casual viewing. Plus, not only is there too much to tackle in one session, if you did break it down, not only would it be more accessible and easier to absorb and digest, you would also make more money. Win-win for everybody! 🎉
author: @mickb69

video_title: The Speaking Coach: The One Word All Liars Use! Stop Saying This Word, It's Making You Sound Weak!

comment_text: This is a rich conversation between Steven and Jefferson. My advice, if you want to transform a negative relationship, treat the person like they’re already a friend. It won’t be easy and you won’t feel authentic, though I guarantee after 5-6 exchanges, the other person will start to shift their behavior. For example, sit next to them in the meeting, give them friendly eye contact, laugh at their joke, even if it’s not funny (cause you know you do that with your friends), offer to grab them a coffee and watch the transformation!
